38756800.review: Amazing adventure game, probably my favorite WEG title now.  There's already plenty of reviews, so I'm just gonna leave it at that.

38748572.review:
This game right here is one of the absolute best point and click adventures I have ever played.  Wadjet Eye Games (WEG) picked a winner in choosing to publish developer Technocrat's gem of a creation.  I loved the story, the voice acting, the puzzles, everything was flawless.  You will ultimately control three different people in the game, Dr. Regis, his faithful sidekick Dr. Lao, and Latha Sesame.  The story starts off and I got the idea this was going to be some kind of cyberpunk, crime mystery type game.  I was totally wrong.  There are so many different elements in this story and what makes it so completely awesome is the fact that almost everything is connected.  I cannot say more than that because this story is something that you should experience on your own.  

It took about 13 hours for one playthrough.  However, I also saved in different sections and knocked out multiple achievements, so it will probably not take quite as long for one playthrough.  However, I will be playing through this again.  The story was beautiful enough that it has replayability.  Whether you find this game at full price or on sale, just pick it up.  If you are a fan of WEG, or point and click adventures...YOU MUST PLAY THIS GAME.

38689044.review: yup, it's good. I have a problem with some of these games becasue the puzzles can have bizarre logic. I keep a game guide open for when I get stuck for an excessive amount of time. 38683867.review:
A solid point & click, with a good story. (Cyberpunk / Future of the Humanity)

You control different characters (2 "cops" & a character addicted to a virtual reality), usually only one at a time. But in some parts it involves up to three of them.

With the character addicted to a virtual reality, i found it was a pretty good idea to use both the real world & the virtual world during the gameplay.

I found the difficulty well balanced : not too hard, not to easy either : count 20-25 hours for the first playthrough. (well in my case, you may take less /  more time to finish the game.). Note : game finished without any help.

Voice acting is pretty good . Music feats very well :  one only small regret  there's no Deluxe Edition on Steam  (like on GOG for example).

I liked a lot some funny situations.  (especially with the french maid :P, well i won't spoil the game)

There are differents endings. Many choices are mostly morals & ethics.

Negative point ; Only avaible in english.

You can turn on / off devs commentary, personnaly i found those annoying.... i would have prefered a separate video.

There's an option in the setup to get a better rendering (since the game was created for using a low resolution : anyway the game scales properly for your screen resolution), but it needs more processing so watch out if your computer isn't powerfull enough.

Another small review, again sorry if english isn't perfect (no translator used).

Enjoy the game, if you buy it.

38653375.review:
Piccola perla che ogni appassionato di avventure grafiche vecchia scuola dovrebbe giocare.
GAMEPLAY: Classico punta e clicca con un comando per osservare ed uno per interagire. Enigmi sempre ben contestualizzati, mai banali ma nemmeno troppo difficili. L'ambientazione cyberpunk ha permesso agli sviluppatori di creare fasi di gameplay ben riuscite che danno freschezza al tipo di gioco, come ad esempio le fasi giocate nel trancenet, una piattaforma internet dove il personaggio entra virtualmente. Menù e opzioni ridotte al minimo sindacale.
STORIA: Sicuramente un punto forte del gioco, la narrazione si sviluppa tra indagini poliziesche, intrecci di più personaggi e un contesto cyberpunk molto ben rappresentato. Le tematiche trattate sono fortemente riservate ad un pubblico adulto e non mancano risvolti interessanti. La caratterizzazione dei personaggi è costruita bene ed è anch'essa pilastro di questo gioco. Longevità che si attesta su buoni livelli, una decina di ore, anche qualcosa in più se si spulcia per bene il gioco con la sua enorme mole di dialoghi.
GRAFICA: Pixel art ispirata, bella per gli appassionati di questo stile e del genere cyberpunk. Tecnicamente però non raggiunge produzioni moderne, sempre in pixel art, come ad esempio Thimbleweed Park. Interfaccia in-game non delle più intuitive.
AUDIO: Colonna sonora adeguata al genere, fa il suo lavoro senza però rimanere impressa. Doppiaggio in inglese ottimamente recitato che fa la parte da leone e sopperisce a molte delle mancanze grafiche/tecniche. Gioco purtroppo non localizzato in italiano.
VOTO: 8

37533559.review:
Technobabylon is an adventure game in the style of - you guessed - beneath a steel sky.
The story and game world are intriguing and there are some plot twists that might come unexpected.
Some choices you make will lead to a few differences in the game world so you can kinda play it your style or assume a roleplay about the characters - will you stay to your morals or give in to temptations, will you help or exploit? It's a nice touch but not that cruicial to the storys development until the ending.
The art style brings up memories from the old days of adventure games and is overall fitting and pleasant to the eye.
The puzzles are not that hard and not too simple.

If you take your time it is a good entertainment for a few evenings. Overall playtime for me was 9-10 hours which is okay for the price. I can definitly recommend this little adventure game gem.

34989299.review:
Solid AGS-based adventure game with a gripping story and interesting characters. It’s sci-fi, but the game doesn’t take itself too seriously. Most of the futuristic things you encounter are based on something that exists today, only taken a few notches further. The setting comes across as a satire of the modern world. So there’s a lot of gags and comedy characters, but it feels somewhat generic.

The puzzles are pretty decent, if a little silly at times. They’re not hard by adventure game standards. I think there were only one or two that got me really stuck. Many puzzles have multiple solutions, which is always nice.

Compared to other AGS games I’ve played, I’d say it’s not quite as good as Gemini Rue or Primordia, but better than The Samaritan Paradox and Shardlight.

34366703.review:
Nos encontramos ante una aventura de corte clásico "point n click". Es un policial ambientado en un mundo ciberpunk en el que tendremos que investigar una serie de asesinatos perpetuados por un asesino conocido como “Mind Jaker” (Roba mentes) y para ello iremos alternando entre Latha una desempleada quien malgasta sus días en el ciberespacio al que llaman “Trance”, Regis un poli de la vieja escuela y a Max su joven compañera quien si bien utiliza “Trance” respeta los métodos de la vieja escuela.

Es recomendable jugar a esta aventura en “Español” al menos que se tenga un muy buen nivel de ingles ya que la historia es algo complicada y hay mucha terminología técnica. Si bien no hay una traducción oficial se puede encontrar sin mucha dificultad (explico mas abajo).

El aspecto gráfico nos hace recordar a las aventuras clásicas de la época dorada. La ambientación esta muy bien lograda, con carteles de neón parpadeantes, pantallas brillantes, grandes edificios, terminales que debemos hackear, personas con implantes cibernéticos, etc. 
De hecho creo que la ambientación es uno de los puntos fuertes de esta aventura, hasta tal punto que a mi forma de ver han sacrificado profundidad en los personajes principales para dar mas “vida” al entorno o personajes secundarios así como también para centrarse en cuestiones técnicas de la historia.

El aspecto sonoro es muy bueno, con música agradable de fondo y con voces muy bien actuadas (en ingles) de absolutamente todos los diálogos.

La jugabilidad es mas que correcta, los puzzles son bastante simples o mejor dicho “lógicos”, salvo una par de cosas algo absurdas al final del juego y solo una “puerta” que a mi ojos era invisible que me hizo recordar como odiaba cuando era mas joven quedar trabado en una aventura por cuestiones de diseño visual mas que por la complejidad de la aventura.

Como contra, que la verdad es bastante subjetivo, podría decir:
- Falta de carisma en los personajes, digamos como que no llegas a encariñarte si lo comparamos con otras aventuras, incluso de la misma desarrolladora, pero por otro lado han enriquecido la ambientación y personajes secundarios.
- La historia un poco desconcertante al principio, mas concretamente en el prologo, pero luego se hace bastante fácil de entender. Da la misma sensación cuando lees esos libros de ciencia ficción que te bombardean con tecnicismos en los primeros capítulos. 
Por otro lado podemos decir nos encontramos con una historia compleja que toca temas que van desde la informática, clonación, inteligencia artificial, ciberespacio, manipulación genética, etc.
- Puede que tengas que ver algún video o guía para resolver algo muy puntual (en mi caso para ver una puerta). A favor tiene que en varias ocasiones tienes distintas formas para resolver una misma cosa y que tiene viarios finales diferentes.
- El logro de rejugarlo con los comentarios de los desarrolladores es molesto, pero por otro lado es menos invasivo que en otras entregas de la misma desarrolladora.... parece que se están dando cuenta.

En resumen, si eres un amante del genero es una aventura debes probar, sobre todo si puedes pillarla en descuento.

Nota:
Hay una traducción que pueden encontrarla perfectamente en Google (Guías Pat & asperet ) para disfrutar del juego en un completo español (las voces seguirán en ingles). 
Deben registrarse en su foro y en la parte de “Traducciones Guías Pat & asperet “, descargar el archivo y descomprimirlo en la carpeta de instalación del juego (C:\Steam\steamapps\common\Technobabylon)

Es recomendable al jugar activar la opción de "Mantener diálogo" en el menú de configuración del juego ya que la historia es complicada y hay mucha terminología técnica, ademas que en algunos momentos los diálogos desaparecen casi de forma instantánea. No se si es por la traducción, pero si les pasa, tan solo darle una vez al espaciador y desaparece el problema.

Puedo dar fe después de haber haberlo pasado 2 veces de que funciona de principio a fin y que no hay absolutamente ningún problema, bug, o nada parecido salvo el mencionado anteriormente.

33689195.review:
A true chapter in an otherwise unpublished Essentials of Cyberpunk Culture: Video Games.

Playing this will invoke memories from such franchises as the Matrix, Blade Runner, and Shadowrun.
While technically a point-and-click puzzle game, if you have any interest in the aforementioned culture, you'll quickly find yourself sucked into this resource-light, lore-heavy game.
With a little ingenuity, players will find this to be a challenge but not overwhelming by any means.

Because it is a suspenseful mystery that you must solve, I won't give too much away.

Early on, we meet some key players in the story. A Trance-addict who's unemployed and living in assigned housing and used to spending most of her time in Technobabylon's version of the Matrix. Two detectives whose personalities compliment each other well - an old-fashioned male and a jack-of-all-trades female, old and young respectively. These two quickly find themselves investigating a murder commited by a suspect who's known only as the Mindjacker.

Admittedly, this is where I saved and took my first break, so I don't know which direction my story will go from here, only that I want to pick this up again very soon and inject myself back into the gritty cyber noir that is Technobabylon.

Cyberpunks or those interested in the culture will find that it reads much like a book that you don't much care to put down. A real page-turner, as it were.

Enjoy, chummers!

33345034.review:
TL;DR - I was blown away by the storyline, character development and atmosphere of this game. This truly is a masterpiece that any lover of science fiction or adventure games needs to experience.

I haven't written a review in quite awhile but felt that this game deserved one. I'm an old gamer (in my mid-30s) and I've played a lot of games in my lifetime. Over the years, I've moved away from the Adventure genre but I started my decades long addiction when LucasArts was in its heyday so I've experienced more than my fair share of these type of games. While this is not the typical style of game I get into these days, I had picked up a copy a while back after reading some stellar reviews. Despite the strong recommendations online, I was honestly very surprised with how quickly I became hooked on this game after I finally got around to loading it up. 

Technobabylon is hands down one of the best storylines I've come across in a video game (a scifi plot as grandiose as any William Gibson or Neil Stephenson novel) and as a storytelling device, the adventure style of gameplay is masterfully implemented to deliver a truly compelling narrative. The graphics are by no means cutting edge but do have a sort of retro-style charm that reminds me strongly of the 90s game "The Dig". The puzzles are at times challenging but also masterfully intuitive. Never was i forced to consult a walkthrough but a few times I did have to walk away to clear my brain so I could reassess the task at hand. Perhaps even more telling is how amazingly the game pulls you into its world. Technobabylon incorporates a number of advanced sci-fi concepts which are very much incorporated into the puzzles but it delivers these concepts naturally so at no point did I feel like the game broke the 4th wall in order to explain some info necessary to move forward. Lastly worth noting were the multiple "choose your own adventure" elements which allowed for divergent paths within storyline. These elements were nothing extraordinary but it did lend the feeling that you were tailoring your own experience based on the subtle choices you made; just another example of the little subtleties that took this game from good to great.

In summary, this game is one of those gems that grabs a hold of you and doesn't let you go until you have completed it at which point your drive to find out what happens is replaced by a sadness that the story has come to an end. It is quite rare that I experience this feeling with a video game.. as it is more common with a good book that you just can't put down. If you like science fiction storylines, adventure games or just good stories in general, do yourself a favor and pick up this game. 10/10

Pros:
+ One of the best storylines I've come across in 25+ years of gaming
+ Playable characters are compelling and offer different playing styles which maintains the game tempo
+ Interface and Inventory interaction are a joy to use (very well implemented)
+ Puzzles are challenging but logically intuitive
+ Scifi concepts are naturally delivered in a way that never breaks the immersion
+ Voice and music audio are very well done
+ Choose your own adventure elements give you a feeling of control without overdoing it to a point where you feel like you are missing a part of the storyline
+ Graphics give the game a retro feel that lovers of the old LucasArts games will appreciate
+ Multiple Endings

Cons:
- Graphics could be fairly classified as outdated and will turn off some gamers
- Upon completion, will create a vacuum in your life which you will need to fill with more sci-fi storylines

33314982.review:
Going into Technobabylon, I didn't expect much as I'm not a huge point-and-click adventure game fan. However, Technobabylon is a real treat and is worth experiencing for fans of any game genre. I would even go as far to say that Technobabylon surpasses Telltale's best games in terms of ingenuity.

The game features a rich story in a dystopian future that may feel convoluted in some areas, though any intelligent individual will appreciate the way the plot is carried out. Without spoiling too much, it deals with murder mysteries and a serial killer who can literally steal the minds of his victims - hence his name, the Mindjacker.

It's full of well-developed characters, intriguing plot twists, and original concepts. The gameplay deals with dialogue-heavy conversations and some challenging puzzles that are incredibly well-designed. In Technobabylon, any items you receive to solve a puzzle make sense in the way they're used. It really plays with your intellect and keeps you sharp the whole way through.

There's also quite a bit of content here. The game took me more than ten hours. Add to that some charming graphics combined with a fantastic soundtrack, and you have one of the best adventure games ever created. Period.

32998550.review:
Technobabylon ist ein Cyberpunk Point & Click Adventure von Technocrat Games und wurde von Wadjet Eye gepublished. Soweit ich es beurteilen kann, ist es das erste "umfangreiche" Spiel des Entwicklers, welches mich dann auch noch derart gepackt und umgehauen hat, aufgrund der genialen Geschichte, der super ausgearbeiten Charaktere, der durchaus originellen Rätsel und nicht zuletzt des Cyperpunk Settings. Beim ersten Wurf ein Volltreffer - Respekt, Technocrat, Respekt! Was macht ihr als nächstes? :)

Die Geschichte spielt in der Stadt Newton im Jahre 2087. Die Stadt wird Schauplatz mehrerer Verbrechen eines so genannten "Mindjacker", der wie der Name schon fast verät, den Verstand und dessen verbunden Erinnerungen seiner Opfer extrahieren und speichern kann.

Der Gesetzesapparat der Stadt wird durch eine adaptive und ständig lernende künstliche Intelligenz namens "Central" gesteuert und überwacht. Central setzt, infolge der Ereignisse, zwei der Protagonisten, die Ermittler Charlie Regis und Max Lao auf den Fall an und beauftragt sie den Verbrecher dingfest zu machen. Welches Motiv der Mindjacker hat bleibt zunächst unklar, es stellt sich allerdings ziemlich schnell heraus, dass auch der dritte spielbare Charakter, die von der Realität in die virtuelle Welt flüchtende Jugendliche Latha Sesame, eine größer Rolle in dem Ganzen spielt.

Fazit: Wenn ihr einen bis ins Detail ausgetüftelten Cyberpunk Krimi sucht, der intelligent, spannend und auch humorvoll ist, dann könnt ihr hier bedenkenlos zugreifen. Einige echt coole Plottwists und Szenarien, die auch ethische Fragen aufwerfen, erwarten euch zusätzlich.

Minimale, technische Schwachpunkte, wie eine etwas zu geringe Auflösung und die sehr rudimentären grafischen Einstellungsmöglichkeiten, hat das Spiel leider ebenfalls, mit denen man aber leben kann - hey, es ist auch ein Adventure Spiel eines Indie Entwicklers und kein Triple-A-Shooter ;). Ich hab es letzendlich im Fenstermodus gezockt, das fand ich persönlich angenehmer. Dieses Manko kann bei mir persönlich nicht über das exzellente Spielerlebnis hinwegtäuschen. Super!

Blade Runner 2D Adventure :-)

Ein bemerkenswert gutes Point & Click Adventure.
Es sieht aus und spielt sich wie ein 25 Jahre altes Retro-Adventure.
Dabei ist der Spielfluss jedoch längst nicht so stocksteif, sondern spielt sich sehr flüssig, da man die Items sehr leicht findet und auch einfach benutzen und kombinieren kann.
Besonders gut ist die Einteilung in mehrere Kapitel, wodurch sich die Laufwege meistens auf einzelne Bildschirme begrenzen und man auch nicht zu viel Items dabei hat.
Die Rätsel sind zumeist sehr logisch aufgebaut und für normale Spieler durchaus zu schaffen.
Es gibt eine großartige Hintergrundgeschichte, die bis zum Schluss spannend bleibt, und sich eindeutig an ein erwachsenes Publikum richtet.
Leider gibt es nur englische Sprachausgabe und Texte, zumindest kann man es so einstellen, dass man die Texte weiterklicken muss und sich in Ruhe alles durchlesen kann, um es zu verstehen.
Freunde der Steam Abzeichen werden sicherlich dutzende Spielstände anlegen, um alle Errungenschaften in einem Rutsch zu meistern. Dann entfällt ein erneuter Durchlauf.
Die Spielzeit ist entsprechend der Story großzügig bemessen.
Abstürze hatte ich keine, ich habe jedoch das Tool Borderless Gaming benutzt, damit ich ohne Probleme bei Vollbildansicht auf den Windows-Desktop wechseln konnte.

Alles in allem ist das Spiel sein Geld absolut Wert und gehört in jede Spielesammlung.

Wertung: 8 / 10 Punkte.

31541116.review:
Another gem from the Wadjey Eye Games studios. 

Set in the future you start playing as an unemployed character who just wants to be in "the Trance" (what the 'net has become). Sadly she's booted out as someone locks her in her apartment. So you work to break out.

Following this opening you're introduced to the other main characters of the game: Regis and Lao who work for CEL which is the game's version of the police. You're tasked with investigating a building where a murder might take place in a little while, as predicted by the central AI of the city.

The controls are intuitive with left-click being action and right-click being "look at". You do have an inventory, accessed from the bottom right of the screen, though you never end up carrying too many items. I will say for me that MOST of the puzzles in this game were fairly logical, with the game providing enough context and ideas for you to work out solutions for yourself. It also helped that, on a few occasions, I couldn't leave the scene I was in without solving all the problems so that narrows down where the solutions must be. 

The main puzzled I struggled with involved me having to leave the building i was in to talk to a man who had appeared outside with no indication. The character was not there when I went in the building. Once I had done that, the rest of the puzzles dropped into place.

I enjoyed exploring the world these characters exist in and seeing this particular interpretation of the future. It's not an interpretation I would care to live in however.  Although I would like to explore "the trance". 

A solid addition to the point-and-click adventure game genre. More please!

Amateur des grands classiques du point''n'click des années 90,  j'ai un peu trainer avant de me lancer dans ce Technobabylon de peur que la difficulté généralement inhérente au genre me rebute.


L'histoire prend place dans un futur plus ou moins proche où la vie des gens est assisté par ordinateur, que ce soit pour se nourrir, se déplacer, où l'internet d'aujourd'hui a été remplacé par un monde virtuel plus vrai que nature. Une sorte d'évolution hardcore des bases établies au début du XXIéme siècle. Vous êtes un agent du CELL, la police locale et vous devrez enquêter sur une série de meurtres qui semblent avoir un lien eux de par le faite que les victimes se font tuer par une sorte de piratage de leur implant cérébrale que tout être humain qui se respecte possède.

Je n'ai pas envi d'aller plus loin dans l'explication de l'histoire pour ne pas vous spoiler. Niveau gameplay, on reste dans le classique : Dialogues, ramassage d'objets, combinaisons d'objets avec en plus la possibilité d'aller dans la "Trance", la réalité virtuelle remplaçant internet dont je parlais plus haut. Les énigmes sont généralements juste mais pas facile, mais certaines s'avereront retords tout en évitant l'écueuil de l'illogisme.

La réalisation visuelle rétro est de bon goût et l'OST du jeu colle parfaitement avec le jeu. Du tout bon.

+
Histoire
Ambiance
OST

-
Certaines énigmes un peu vénére

Fantastic game. If you like adventure games with a well-told story and interesting characters set in a cyberpunk dystopian world then this is the game for you. It is a slow burner though. In the beginning you will be mostly wondering what it is all about while you are slowly introduced to all the characters and the setting iself - but soon it all comes together and what a tale it is. I really enjoyed it.

The puzzles aren't too intense, had to look up two things while playing. First one I just failed to understand how the terminal I was using in-game was supposed to work, but as soon as I looked it up it made sense. Another problem was at the end and required a "timing" -element. Was not ready for that but that problem also made sense in retrospect.

Otherwise the graphic is retro, but full with color and detail. The voice acting is superb throughout the game. Characters talk and act in a believable way.

I recommend it highly if you like point & click adventure games and want a good story that last for quite a while. I took me around 12 hours to complete the game.

30737379.review:
About one-third of the way through, I'm finding this to be an excellent point-n-click adventure game with a compelling story and atmosphere. The puzzles are well thought out (so far) and the developers have done an excellent job avoiding outlandish combinations, a major weakness of many games in this genre.

The story, game design, art, voice acting, dialogue are all top notch and easily exceeded my expectations. And the whole is more than the sum of its parts. Surprisingly, Technobabylon kind of seems to have flown under the radar. It deserves more attention and love from discerning gamers of the unhurried variety.

Highly recommended, a 9.5/ 10 for me in this genre and style. After completing, will edit this review to revise and add to these impressions.

Update after completing Technobabylon:
-----------------------------------------------------
The game is as good, solid and well thought out as in my initial impression above. If not more. Game design is particularly good, there is coherency and no dead ends. The puzzles are excellent and satisfying- I never had to consult a guide. The writing is first class and thought provoking, with many science and technology themes explored.

On an ending note, Technobabylon gives many opportunities to interact with characters, and they should be seized to appreciate the story that much more. As before, a splendid 9.5/ 10.

30707790.review: Technobabylon gets it right where many AAA games fail. Mystery story that will suck you in like a black hole, only to spit you back out to reality, tired but satisfied. Suprisingly relatable and believeable characters, decent puzzles that are neither too easy, but also not too hard (if you can use your brain, that is) make the story-flow smooth and enjoyable, all in lovable oldschool graphics. Despite plethora of other options - few games deliver like Technobabylon.

30699923.review:
Absolutely amazing adventure game.

The best part of this game was easily the characters. A wide variety of characters with distinct personalities, and each with actually pretty good voice acting! To top it off, this game does something many others fail to do. This game actually had diversity in its characters. Characters ranging in age, sexuality, gender and nationality, and all of them well written. You even get to play as two characters that ARE NOT an old white guy (and hey I loved Dr Regis despite that).

The story was really gripping and interesting, the gameplay was simple but it worked better than many other adventure games, and the all the visuals were wonderful. The music wasn't too great but it wasn't annoying at anypoint.

The only real issues I had with the game was some simple bugs, that were more an issue of the AGS engine than anything else. Characters clipping through walls during animations, elevators getting stuck, that sort of thing.

The puzzles were, up until one bit in the very last section, sensible and fun. At no other point did I hate a puzzle for making no sense or give in to looking it up. 

Highly reccomend this game to anyone who likes cyberpunk or adventure games.

30593658.review:
I was skeptical to begin with but this turned out to be one of the best adventure games I've played, I would definitely recommend it. 

+The puzzles are logical and don't involve the usual inventory spamming so endemic in this type of game. The signaling is great and if you get stuck you can usually get a decent nudge in the right direction by talking to everyone. 

+The game is broken up into ten chapters and each chapter takes place in a relatively small area with a limited inventory so things never become overwhelming. 

+The voice acting and dialog are great, though they start out a little shaky (this may be to do with the fact that chapters 1-3 were made years before the rest of the game was finished). As the game progresses you'll encounter loads of memorable and well fleshed out characters oh my yes. 

+The world building is excellent and though there is quite a lot of technobabble in the dialog (it's right there in the title) it's incorporated well enough into the story and puzzle that it doesn't feel gratuitous. 

-My only major criticism is that the last chapter is LITTERED with bugs. I didn't encounter anything that prevented my progress but I stopped trusting the game at that point and when I got stuck I presumed it was because of a bug not a puzzle.

30535332.review:
If you're a fan of old school point-and-click adventure games, this game will not disappoint you. The writing is so good I barely have to add the phrase "for a game" to it.

The use-item logic puzzles are quite good, too. I rarely used the walkthrough to get past difficult parts. Most could be figured out by just reasoning through it. Invariably, there will be a time (or two) where you look up a problem only to find out it was an element in the environment that you didn't recognize. These moments are rare.

The story presents you with authentic moral choices which actually matter insofar as you care about what's happening because the characters are very well drawn. If you are confused about someone's motivations, then it's because the writers meant it, not due to poor design.

The game isn't long, but that's a feature, not a bug. I didn't feel like this game was wasting my time and will definitely play another by these developers.

30530446.review:
Una de las mejores aventuras gráficas a las que he jugado, con un mundo y unos personajes que me encantó ir descubriendo. Me he quedado con ganas de más, pero no porque el juego sea corto, tiene una buena duración para su género y dos finales bastante diferentes, ninguno claramente mejor que el otro.

Se trata de una historia Cyberpunk ambientada en una ciudad-estado del futuro, y vamos controlando a tres personajes: dos detectives y una joven adicta a la red. La relación que los une entre sí y a una serie de crímenes se va desvelando al avanzar la historia. El juego trata bajo una óptica de ciencia-ficción temas como la bioingeniería y sus posibles usos, tanto constructivos como destructivos, la conexión directa entre cerebros humanos, máquinas y la red, o el desarrollo de la inteligencia artificial.

Los personajes son complejos, interesantes, y a veces encantadores o incluso graciosos, a pesar de la siniestra trama en la que se ven envueltos. Además entre ellos hay representación de distintos orígenes étnicos y sexualidades, y uno de los personajes principales es, entre muchas otras cosas, una mujer trans, sin que este rasgo la defina. Estas cosas no tienen un peso especial en la trama, simplemente están ahí.

Los puzles son satisfactorios, que es de lo mejor que se puede decir, tanto por su diseño y su, por lo general, equilibrada relación dificultad/lógica, como por el entorno argumental en el que se desarrollan. Hay casos en que tienes distintas opciones para resolver un mismo problema, y a veces lo que elijas repercute en diálogos o detalles secundarios de capítulos posteriores, pero en nada demasiado importante hasta el área del final, en la que una acción decide entre los dos desenlaces.

Sé que para alguna gente será un problema la cuestión del idioma, porque es un género que usa bastante texto y solo está en inglés. Pero si eso no te molesta, y te gustan las aventuras gráficas, a mí esta me parece una pasada.

30368843.review: Fantastic. Thought provoking with a great story and characters. A good throwback to old school point and clicks also with just the right level of challenge.

30213996.review:
非常好的冒险点击类游戏。2067年，一群精英科学家组成了一个团队，目的是开发出一个前所未有的强大AI。其不同之处在于这个AI使用了生物工程技术，有类似神经系统的结构，而这一技术得以研发，依靠了当时团队里的查理和维克莎夫妇提供的自己的试管胚胎。不过一次严重的事故，却让这个团队的成员损失了一半....20年后的2087年，被成功研发的名叫“中央”的AI正井井有条的管理着纽顿市，纽顿市新一代的市民通过基因工程改造，可以随时进入虚拟空间trance（类似于现在的互联网），与其他人交互，与“中央”衔接，获取讯息，‘中央’也可以反过来获取市民的讯息，做好规划。
    这时的查理已经是一名警探，有“中央”的指导解决案件已经不需要人类动脑思考。因为拒绝接入‘中央’，查理身边被安排了一名年轻的劳警官，也因此被笑话是老古董，可是没有人知道查理在20年前参与了‘中央’的研发。平静的纽顿市最近接连发生谋杀案件，凶手的目标是攫取受害者脑内存储的信息，直觉告诉查理有人想对‘中央’做文章。然而查理并不知道的是，当年他和维克莎的试管胚胎，有一个被孕育产下。这个和‘中央’有着相同基因表型的女孩，查理并不知晓的女儿，会成为解决这次事件的关键吗？
    游戏的剧情不错，谜题难度适中。但是如果英语不好的话，对剧情的理解，谜题的难度都会大大提升。

CONS

29733301.review:
Incredibly underrated gem. One of the best (possibly the best actually) point-and-click I've ever played.
Story starts out kinda confusing but it doesn't take too long to start getting good. 88% of the voice acting is really great (Only a couple actors I thought were a bit sub-par) And the pixel art, oh my goodness the artwork in this game is incredible. One of the best looking cyberpunk worlds I've ever seen, absolutely loved it. Also the soundtrack is just *perfect* for setting the mood in any scene/area of the game, it compliments it flawlessly.
I'd very well say this may be one of my favorite games of all time. It really is THAT good.
Definitely the kinda game that should be played at a slower pace though, take your time to talk to everyone, read everything, and just get invested/immersed in it. Cause if ya do it makes the whole thing a whole lot more enjoyable (And the story a lot more understandable)
Also I almost forgot to mention how great *most* of the puzzles are (only 2 or 3 I thought had some weird solutions) But the amount of items you can interact with in an area is usually limited to only things you NEED to interact with, so that helps a lot with solving puzzles, but also almost every puzzle actually makes sense, which isn't something that can be said for a LOT of point-and-click games.

Overall, this game's great go buy it. :P
5/5 - Flawed, but everything else is just so dang good I don't even mind it.

29536482.review:
Now, right off the bat; credit where credit is due: there is a lot of work that was put into this. This was clearly someone's passion project. Either that or someone's first stab at making something so cohesive and interesting. It was a valiant effort on the creator's part. And I want to stress my appreciation for the talent and effort put into this. Even if I can't really sink my teeth into it personally. From the art to the lore to the voice talent, you can tell that people really labored over this; that much is evident. However, there are some parts missing here. There are some ingredients missing from the soup,

Technobabylon is a story about a futuristic world that couldn't care less. Cloned babies, overbearing artificial intelligence, zero privacy, escapism, nuclear war, and the ever present looming threat of scarcity masked as abundance. Everything is here and accounted for. What I can give Technobabylon credit for is how it presents its setting. It doesn't bother to bombard you. It gives you clues about this world you're experiencing. And aside from a set of very specific situations, it isn't required that you care at all about this setting. The characters themselves clearly don't. That's a little more believable in my opinion. If we all lived in the dystopia, I'd doubt that anyone would care after so long. That's natural for these characters, and this is shown in game. Kudos.

Now, I'm going to have to take those kudos right back, because for these steps forward, Technobabylon makes some very curious design choices. I know it's the future in all, but this game has a bizarre fixation on fitting in some heavyweight rhetoric in the wrong places. What do I mean? Well, early in the game we learn that one of the major characters underwent a sex change. Wowee. And this is just mentioned in passing. Never comes up. Never adds much to the character other than a moment of, "uhh.. ok?" If anything this soured my vision of one of the characters right off the bat. Why would I care about a character's gender? Or past gender? Especially if this point was treated with none of the tact and meaning that a subject like this usually requires.

Later in the game we're introduced to a homosexual couple who have a synthetic housemaid who's strongly implied to be assisting them in the bedroom. Did I say strongly implied? I mean outright stated. Now, that's fantastic and all, but this is just dropped and left to sit there. The most we know about them is they like Paris. That's about it... Again, no investment. No meaning whatsoever. Strike two. The last straw came late in the game when I witnessed the fastest devolution of what could've been mildly entertaining dialogue into what was essentially akin to "mind your pronouns." Apparently the distinction between gynoid and android is very important? Also, points for me reacting almost exactly like the villain did.

Contrast this with the only straight relationship in the game: Regis and his wife. This relationship isn't impactful because its straight, its impactful because it plays a significant role in these character's motivations. It plays into the plot a lot more. It actually contributes. In fact, this point would've remained entirely unchanged if it were a homosexual relationship anyway. I feel like the game tried to make it a point to include these things but ended up making them completely insubstantial as a result.

As far as the rest of the game goes, I can say everything blends together more or less. It does the setting well, like I said, but failure to utilize this and make something meaningful just leads to more disappointment. The characters are serviceable. So is the plot. It really comes down to how predictable you like your point and click games. I could guess the big twist about two hours before I actually completed the game. And while I'm throwing stones, the last area and the ending are so horribly contrived that it ruins anything the game was trying to set up. Some special thread of voodoo magic is tying these character's fates together. It's up to Regis Philbin and two other people to save the world I guess.

For what it's worth, this is an alright experience. I wouldn't recommend it for a few reasons. The later half of the game suffers from lack of direction, and it all trails into the worst parts of the game. Puzzles fall into two categories: immediately obvious and impossible. Out of the entire cast, Regis was the only one I was vaguely interested in. The entire rest of the cast was more or less forgettable or boring. And the big top off is the ending. For the asking price, this is an alright game to put some hours into. But honestly, I just don't regard it as exceptional.

29451942.review:
I love point & click games and I love cyberpunk. Those are two excellent reasons to love this game. But I have more to say about it.

Point & click + cyberpunk is a rather common combination, these days. For example, see Read Only Memories, Void & Meddler, Gemini Rue... All these games are good, but Technobabylon is definitely the best I've ever played.

All characters are very interesting, full of surprises.

The scenario is clever, unexpected, easily believable, easily understandable, and full of interesting moral dilemmas.

There are two great endings. It's very hard to say which one is the best.

Musics and graphics are both beautiful. Voice actors are great.

As in most cyberpunk games, there is a queer side, but it is not too invasive, unlike in many others (see Read Only Memories and Void & Meddler, for example, that can be annoying here). This aspect of the game is balanced correctly.

When you'll finish this game, your first thought will be: "when do they create a second episode? I want more!"

29365806.review: good throwback to the point and click adventures i played as a kid.  good story..little heavy on the dialogue, but it kept me interested.  not too long, not too short

29339041.review:
Le avventure targate Wadjet sono ormai tra i migliori prodotti del genere e Technobabylon non fa eccezione.
Ambientazione cyberpunk splendida, storia e tematiche ottimamente scritte e gestite, per nulla banali (forse giusto il twist finale è abbastanza prevedibile); lato gameplay, i puzzle sono ben congeniati, perfettamente integrati, tutti logici e mai inutilmente complessi.

29309094.review: There is great sci-fi writing here, and the game themes are among the most interesting questions about our future.

29304842.review:
Solid old-school adventure game. The first point&click adventure I've played I think where many puzzles have more than one solution. Storywise it's reminiscent of classic cyberpunk - Neuromancer et al. This is what I wanted Beneath A Steel Sky to be back in the days.

One minor recurring bug - sometimes pop up windows (like when you examine something) instantly closes again. Saving, quitting and reloading fixed it though.

All in all, highly recommended.

29289040.review: LOVED THIS GAME ! I almost uninstalled after the first 10 minutes due to the graphics, sure glad I didn't ! My god this thing was a masterpiece point and click puzzler imo! Great story, music..etc!

29257365.review:
A point and click adventure.

These kinds of games rely on the story. The game takes place in the future, where the city of Newton is controlled by a central computer and the internet is now multiple virtual worlds that you can access with your brain. Most of the time you control two characters, Latha, an internet adict, and Charlie, a police detective. That's pretty much the introduction to avoid spoilers.

I found the story interesting but as always it is often hard to figure out what to do. However if you're not fond of searching or figuring out random puzzles like myself, you can just check a walkthrough on the internet. Still, the puzzles aren't hard to figure out and I did not get stuck that much.

Recommended if you like point and click adventures.

29184558.review: Very well designed, deep story. Reminded me of the old point and click RPG from Sierra, but with a twist.

29180579.review:
Fantastic game, well written, cool music, cool world. I never finished Beneath a Steel Sky, but I completed Technobabylon. I'm telling all my friends about it.

There are 10 chapters in total, which I completed in about 10 hours over as many evenings, and it felt very well paced. The experience was much like reading a novel, but one which I was a part of. A prime example of computer game as literary form. 

Reviewer: Male, 38, Computer Scientist, grew up watching Blade Runner and Aliens.

29171539.review:
The visuals, the characters, thematic context and music.. it all comes together nicely.

There are only 2 difficult puzzles (and only 1 of them, would I consider truly "unfair" - the double conduit one near the end). The rest are not only quite logical in context, but makes you feel intelligent for considering such options, even if the game is actively dropping hints about it.

The ending has (I think) 2 possible outcomes, not sure how much the dialogue changes, though. I went through the "good" one.

Overall, once of the best Cyberpunk games out there.  
Genuinely enjoyed it. Hope there is a sequel soon.

Extra: Enable the Director's comments. They all come up as very likeable, and their interjections where pretty insightful.

29136798.review:
I enjoyed playing through this cyberpunk point & click adventure game. I liked the  story and the setting and the puzzles for the most part made sense. I only had to look for help on how to proceed at a couple points.  I really like that at several parts in the game you have more than one option for solving the problem at hand. It took me about 12 hours to beat the game and the extra time logged has been  me exploring the other story options. 
The AI splitter tool they have I found  to be entertaining. I liked how they simulated the AI acting as a different personality than its own by having the voice actor imitate the other character's voice. 
My big complaint might be because I have dual monitors, but a common problem I had would be the game not constraining mouse movement to the primary monitor, so it would click on the desktop of the second monitor and minimize the game  until I click back on the game in the taskbar to bring it back up (until it would happen  again later). 
Overall though, I found this game to be entertaining and recommend it to anyone into cyberpunk & adventure games.

29135544.review:
One of the best Point & Click adventure games I've ever played. The puzzles are challenging, but not impossibly hard. It's a great story with some twists and turns, and also filled with some memorable characters.
I can't recommend it enough!

29131760.review:
Definitivamente, uno de los mejores guiones que he encontrado en juegos indies desde hace mucho tiempo. Me encantó esa mezcla de historia de ciencia ficción basada en la idea de una red de interconexión de realidad virtual en una ciudad controlada por una IA, que en combinación con la estética 8-bit y el entorno de metrópoli llena de rascacielos con luces de neón, le da un aire retrofuturista que me hace sentir nostálgico, como si estuviese leyendo una novela de William Gibson.

Mi única crítica, es la dificultad de algunos de los puzzles: aunque en su mayoría son bastante sencillos, en al menos 3 ocasiones tuve que buscar walkthoughs para poder llegar a la solución, y en cada uno de esos casos sentí que los pasos que había que seguir eran demasiado rebuscados, llenos de condiciones excesivamente específicas y no muy coherentes que hay que cumplir para completar la acción.

Fuera de eso: disfruté todas y cada una de las casi 20 horas de juego que me eché.

29130650.review:
[b]tl;dr[/b]
Technobabylon has an amazing narrative setting and will impress you with its very down-to-earth take on cyberpunk philosophy, technology and social themes. On the other hand, the game itself is only average for a point-and-click adventure. Fortunately, it lets its narrative parts shine through it.

[b]Full version[/b]

Being a cyberpunk fan, I bought Technobabylon hoping to experience a good cyberpunk story, and in that regard, I was more than satisfied. The game's strongest point is definitely how clever, well thought out and realistic its narrative setting is. Throughout my experience, I kept thinking that if I was transported 50-100 years in the future, I'd be hearing about exactly these issues on the news. I particularly enjoyed how social issues and ethical decisions in technology are at the forefront of this story, in a way that is completely believable. This game is definitely a love letter to the cyberpunk genre by someone who has reflected a lot on it, and that person has my warm thanks for it.

As a game however, Technobabylon has its share of drawbacks.

In terms of atmosphere, the art is not so appealing, although the portraits during conversations are really nice. The overall art direction is functional and supports the theme. Voice acting is ok. Music fits, but is not inspiring.

The story is really great, but would be more appropriate for a book/movie. I find it loses some of its luster here because it's really convoluted. It showcases multiple protagonists, antagonists and secondary characters, goes back and forth between past and present, and jumps from one character's perspective to the next all the time. This could have worked very well if it had been delivered more gradually, but because this story only coalesces at the very end, you spend 80% of the game quite confused by it.

And this is made especially a problem because of the difficulty of the puzzles. They are not difficult in the sense of requiring great intellectual feats to solve, but rather in the sense of "how on earth did they want me to guess I should do this sequence of things to reach this scene's not-even clearly stated objective". Granted, I consider myself a casual in terms of point-and-click adventures, in the sense that I want the story to unfold with a good flow and the puzzles to be easy and intuitive. This is how I generally felt with Gemini Rue for example, another cyberpunk point-and-click published by Wadjet Eye. But here, in every single scene, I found myself stuck, not knowing how to advance to the next part. I had to make generous use of a walkthrough to move through the game. After reading the solutions, I often found that there was no way I could have thought about doing that, and so it reduced greatly my enjoyment and desire to even try in the next scene. The other downside of this difficulty was that all of my brainpower went into trying to solve puzzles, which made it much harder to focus on the strengths of this game: it's atmosphere and story.

To conclude, if you are a fan of cyberpunk stories, you should definitely try this game; you'll be greatly rewarded narratively for it, especially if you don't mind using a walkthrough. If you don't care for cyberpunk and are primarily a point-and-click adventure fan, there are definitely better games out there for you. I guess hardcore point-and-click fans who love difficult puzzles might enjoy it.

Thanks, Technocrat Games, for a great story!

29130007.review:
Ez a játék azért keltette fel a figyelmemet, mert egyrészt klasszikus point and click kalandjáték, másrészt, mert sci-fi, harmadrészt pedig, mert a kiadó a Wadjet Eye Games, akiknek a Blackwell kvadrológiát köszönhetjük, ami egyik kedvenc kalandjáték-sorozatom. A játék 2087-ben játszódik. 3 karaktert irányítunk. Egy CEL (rendőrségszerű) szervezetnek dolgozó fickót, a társát, valamint egy csajt, aki munkanélküli és trancefüggő (virtuális valóságszerű valami, ami egyben olyasmi is, mint az internet). A játék igazából minden ponton erős. A megalkotott világ érdekes és részletes és nagyon kidolgozott mind technológia, mind a társadalom szempontjából. A karakterek érdekesek, sztori jó (néha vicces, sokszor komor) néhány meglepő fordulattal, hangulat jön ezerrel. Játékmenetben hozza a hagyományos point and click receptet, szal dumák, tárgyak összeszedése, használata, kombinálása. Van pár nehezebb rész, de mindenhol sikerült magamtól rájönnöm a megoldásra. Ami a játékmenetben érdekes, h sokszor a virtuális valóságban kell valamit megtennünk, előtte rákapcsolódva különböző gépekre, tárgyakra, amiket MI vezérel. Ami még tetszett, h vannak benne döntési lehetőségek és több befejezés közül választhatunk. Grafikára nem sokat lehet mondani, oldschool pixelgrafika, jól megrajzolt hátterekkel, karakterportrékkal és meglepően jó animációkkal.

Szóval összességében nagyon bejött. Nem nagyon tudok kifogásolnivalót találni rajta.

29097888.review: If you like the style of old fashioned point-and-click adventures, definetively get this one! It has a really immersive, rich story. The puzzles are not to easy - it's not just a story you click through as is the case with a lot of too easy adventures these days. They did a great job!

29086022.review:
[h1]A Great Sci-fi novel[/h1]

Technobabylon is one of these games that I bought on sales and let in my library for weeks, asking myself if I will ever play it. I finally did, and it was one of my greatest experience in point-and-click.

The one thing that makes this game GREAT is the vision of future it embraces. It isn't yet another utopia/distopia, it's a blending of plausible, mature extrapolations of nowaday's tendencies in technology and social life. You will find many things to think about, dream or fear about, in this game's vision of our future. News and secondary characters strongly participate in creating this wonderful atmosphere. 

This game acted on me like a wonderful book, when you appropriate the author's universe and make it your own, thinking about it for the rest of the day, talking about it with collegues, friends and family. If you like science fiction, you'll LOVE Technobabylon.

One more thing: beyond the incredible story and atmosphere, the point'n'click mechanics are great, and the puzzles are always logical. You don't find solutions by trying - like - the potato on the ceiling, you know what I mean, point'n'click players! And it is very well balanced. Go play it now, the developers deserve it :)

29004257.review: The writing and vocal work are pretty good, all things considered. It was an interesting take on the cyberpunk setting. The gameplay is pretty standard point-and-click adventure, though, and it's fairly short. Worth a playthough if you can get it on a sale.

28907911.review:
Excellent production values and story in this, cyber punk, sci-fi, point and click game. They did a good job of defining a world beyond just that of the story. The art direction is top notch. I really appreciated the throwback aesthetic. The voice acting is very well done too.

In terms of game play, this is pretty standard stuff.  I was pleasantly surprised that for large portions of the game I was able to figure out myself what needed to be done ... but like all point and click games, it suffers from obtuse puzzles that, at least for me, don't seem solvable without a walkthru. However, I only had to resort to those less than a handful of times.

I wouldn't mind seeing more of these characters in another adventure.

28897585.review:
Absolutely loved it.

I'm someone who doesn't do well with games that require reaction times, coordination, or patience, so basically I don't really expect any games to be totally fulfilling to me. But shit, I guess I didn't see Technobabylon coming. I'll admit I had to refer to walkthroughs for a lot of the second half of this game, but honestly I wish I hadn't because all the puzzles are actually completely achievable if you think about them long enough (again, patience isn't a strong point for me).
All of the gameplay aspects totally hooked me right off the bat - I started this game right on the cusp of Christmas and the New Year, and I spent a lot of moments that probably should have been spent celebrating playing this game instead. I have no regrets. Awesome start to 2017. This game gave me clear skin, cured my depression and inspired me to achieve more. 

Anyway, that's before we even get to the characters. Honestly the characters in any game always make or break it for me, and in this case they totally made it. Charlie is incredibly sweet and easy to relate with, Latha is simulateously adorable and the coolest protagonist ever, and Lao is a fucking boss. This is the point where my stupidly in-depth review that noone is gonna read gets more spoilery and much more contentious, but it had a massive impact on my experience so I'm just gonna have to go there...
A large problem people seem to perceive with minority characters is this idea that they only exist for the creator to show off how 'socially aware' they are. I mostly see people who aren't part of the minority groups at hand talking about this, and honestly, the only way you could make any kind of insightful critisism of a minority character is if you ARE that minority. I know we all like to think that we can think through every puzzle in the world whether it's race or gender, but I've had to learn over a long time that it's definitely not as simple as just thinking objectively. 
As a white person in New Zealand, I do all I can to advocate against racial violence, because I'm never going to experience having my rights as a white person being subtly exploited on a grand scale, via laws implemented by other white people back when you could sell human beings. 
Any opinion I have on Lao's writing or characterisation as an East Asian character are never going to be as good or in depth as those of any given Asian person, because I just don't know what it's like to be Asian. Even just under the general title of 'transgender' I'm sure you can hear a million different feelings and interpretations on Max Lao, from people with massively different experiences and perspectives. With this in mind, that's why I roll my eyes when I see people who aren't transgender talking smack about the presence of trans characters in media. If you want to help keep damaging or stupid characterisations out of games, any of the people writing those reviews will probably give you lots of stuff to look out for (see: the trope of being outed against one's will).

WITH THAT BEING SAID. I loved Lao. I love how her backstory is revealed, I love how she is the one who CHOOSES to reveal it to Charlie on her own terms, and I love how for once I got to play a game that doesn't decide to have a protagonist who can probe the trans character with invasive or demeaning questions *cough Dragon Age Inquisition cough*. Obviously those interactions have their place, but Jesus, we get it already. There are more interesting conversations to see about a character being trans than just that. The world will not suffer for having one less game where a character gets interrogated on why she chose to be a girl. 
As anyone who's still reading has probably guessed at this point, I'm transgender myself, but I don't know what it's like to be raised as a boy and then try and carve my way from there. It's a hugely different experience and there is a lot to Lao that I honestly can't really say whether it's done right or not, I just wouldn't know. 
And I mean even aside from all this, it's really a pretty miniscule plot point, so I don't know if I missed anything but there's not really a whole lot of room FOR a problem. This makes it seem like it was a humungous part of the game and it really wasn't, as with a lot of other minority appearances, re: the interracial gay couples I've seen someone get massively upset over. As well as a robot that they claimed to be gay, with no supporting evidence. But that's none of my business. 
There's not really much I can say about the other minority appearances in this game, other than 'they were there'. It would've been a really cool opportunity to have a disabled character that wasn't a villain, but again, I don't really know much more about that - maybe we'll see that in the next installment from these guys! 

I LOVE this game. It wasn't perfect, but I definitely didn't see this review coming when I bought this game and had I known I would've happily paid more. I'm definitely going to be recommending this to people in the future, and keeping tabs on the team behind it because they were the ones who DECIDED for make such bold claims for this game, and it paid off. I'm excited for even bolder games from them in the future - more self-loving transgender characters, please!! :D

28897162.review:
This game will not dissapoint you. I had a lot of fun playing it.

28892537.review:
Technobabylon looks very polished for the engine it was made in. The visuals are the first thing that draws my eye. It's futuristic landscape and location both in the physical world and virtual are incredibly eye catching. In this adventure you play a detective on the trail of a serial killer and a net junky who has been suffering a series of unfortunate events if you will. 

Starting off you aren't exactly sure how these two character's stories seem to connect and that's an underlying mystery as they both have missions of their own, crossing but for the most part independent of one another. The story itself while is not hard to follow does have a lot of science and a bit of technical jargon mixed in but nothing too hard to follow. Each chapter is great at giving you a piece of the bigger picture without completely confusing the player and I appreciated when I got to experience past events that helped explain our main detective's state of mind. This all leads to a natural progressions of things and events that come together so smoothly. When you have that "aha" moment it just fits and everything makes sense. 

As with most adventure games you have your fair share of puzzles. The beginning is where I was most frustrated because it confused me how I would take a physical object into the internet realm but after that initial segment puzzles were a bit easier. They required a bit of thinking. A lot of moving my mouse over random stuff to see if I could click it and a lot of paying attention to my surroundings and conversations. There's various puzzles in each chapter and usually you're putting your detective skills to good use. I found the final set of puzzles particularly clever and fun to figure out because you had to utilize all 3 characters to solve it. 

This game by far has the best representation of online interactions, even a torturous little mini-game by the name of Gravball, which happens to be human Pong. I must have spent the better part of half an hour trying to beat the computer legit. Even with the game being linear I never felt like I was stuck in an area for too long. Things never got stale or boring. It's rare that an adventure can keep my interests straight through. And I didn't think it suffered any of the pitfalls that other games seem to possess. 

So in short you've got a beautiful, fast paced game with intelligent varied puzzles. Decent voice acting and music which never gets stale. I think Technobabylon is one of Wadjet Eye's better games and if you're a fan of futuristic, science-y detective games then you should definitely put this one on your "to play" list.

I liked it a lot, until a gamebreaking bug near the end killed it for me. The story was relatively interesting, and I liked the characters well enough. They follow stereotypes a bit too much for me and sometimes some actions are unbelievable for me. However, it wasn't that bad, and I still liked the game. 

Then, I spent about an hour and a half trying to finish the last chapter, but it just didn't work. [spoiler]I put the grenade in the drone and tried both ways; I sent it toward the power supply - machinery ate the drone. I sent it underneath towards the Mindjacker - machinery still ate the drone. I tried it multiple times with a little variation. I put the grenade in with each different character - even Latha. Never worked. Tried reloading to the end of the last chapter, but still couldn't get past this part when I got to it. Totally frustrating since I really wanted to finish the game and see the end.[/spoiler] Good game, but that bug just utterly destroyed my enjoyment.

28431790.review:
Technobabylon is a great point-and-click adventure, with puzzles being exactly right in terms of difficulty. It's sometimes a little hard to keep up with the story, though.

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
[list]
[*]Has a good story, explained from various points of view that inevitably cross paths, of course :)
[*]The game throws a fair challenge at you and doesn't give too many hints. I felt that it was balanced just right.
[*]Great cyberpunk theme, being slightly ahead of us but not thousands of years.
[*]Great voice acting by various characters. 
[*]Branching choices, and multiple endings
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]The graphics. Don't get me wrong, I love nostalgic pixel graphics, but the game initially ran at a 640x800 resolution and after bumping that up the sprites became so awful I decided to scale back down, but that didnt look so great either. Not acceptable for a game of this day and age.
[*]The whole game's universe doesn't explain itself well enough sometimes. With various technical jargon thrown in between it just gets a little confusing sometimes. This also goes for the mainstoryline - Though it was good, I sometimes had the idea that I was missing things.
[/list]

Want a nostalgic point-and-click adventure in a sci-fi setting? Technobabylon is a great game for you!

28393418.review:
Very good game ...

... immersing you in a big universe, 
... telling an interesting, twisting story,
... offering a lot of riddle and storytelling gameplay.

What was the best for me: This world is full of things to discover. Basically in every scene you get hints about bigger things going on outside of the actual story. This universe is full, complex, seducive.

As in "Germini Rue", the story is serious, grown-up and complex ... with separate storylines getting entagled. The concern then is (and it is not fully ruled out) that not all details of the storylines add up or are fully covered. But this times, in the last chapter, they do a lot to add one and one together and to explain the big plot governing all the separate stories. 

And here, in this last chapter, is my single point of critic about the storytelling: They do too much! If you want you can get expansive explanations by three or more characters. For one, if you really go through all the dialouges then, the final loses its pacing (so much time for talk when danger is imminent?). And secondly, not all of the dialouge options then add up in a sensible order.
But that is a bit "splitting hairs". The story is good! I enjoyed my hours in the city of Newton, in the year 2087.

28351481.review:

28314419.review:
Sigh, Technobabylon.  A game that many people call one of the best new adventure games.  It's really not.  It's very nostalgic and a great call back to the adventure games of the past, but that's where it belongs in the past and not now.  First off, this horrendous pixel style needs to stop.  It's bad, real bad.  It looks ugly, trying to copy the pixel graphic style of games older than Kings Quest 5 is just not something I want to see.  I assume some people do, but I have no idea why.  At worst it should have the clean visual style of the Moneky Island remasters games.  I know this studio loves their pixel graphics, but harenking back to the terrible graphics of the past is not the way to go. 

You play the game as 3 different characters.  A senior detective on the police force, who is kind of this old curmudgen who hates technology and dislikes the direction the future has taken (also he is from Texas...apparently in the future Texans have no accents).  His partner, a young female detective who is a computer expert and is very much on board with the direction the future has taken and all set to accept her AI overlords.  Finally, a young female hacker, who is addicted to the internet and spends her entire life in the internet...hacking?  Of these three i liked the female detective the most and really just wanted to play the game as her the whole time, which is unfortunate because she probably has the least amount of time in the game. 

On the up side this game is far better than Gemini Rue.  The voice acting is better, the puzzles are better, the environments are better.  I really thought the voice actors did a fine job, certainly not the best job, but a fine job.  The puzzles are a lot less pixel hunty than Gemini Rue which is great.  However, the puzzles also aren't very good. They certainly don't take a lot to figure out.  I only found myself stuck on the very last puzzle in the game which involved a wrench and I had to eventually just give up.  I'm pretty confident i would never have figured it out as it required me to do something that I didn't even think was possible.  The rest of the puzzles are mainly easy, because their are very few items in the environment to click on, so most of the time i was just stumbling into solutions without even thinking.

Really, though I can forgive basically anything so long as the story is good, which is also where this game fails the most.[spoiler] I certainly like the world the game created.  This idea that after countless wars cities start to use AI to govern and administer is intriquing.  A wonderful cyberpunk setting.  Sadly, i thought i was getting a detective story in this setting, what I got was kind of a mishmash government conspiracy story and although you are a detective the story really just flows without you doing much detecting.  Oh sure the plot makes your main character out to be one of the best detectives...which is nonsensical considering you are also the greatest scientist...who i guess felt a career change to detective was a better choice?  It doesn't make any sense.  The plot moves along with your detecting mainly being stumbling into situation after situation without ever really figuring out or discovering anything.  I figured out who was behind the murders in the first hour of the game, but not due to any clues, simply because they came off as super evil and there were no other characters in the game.  The motive is revealed in an info dump near the end of the game...but you never had any clues to figure it out beforehand.  I find these types of mysteries maddening.  It shows a great lack of ability in the writing, they don't understand how to lay out a trail of clues or introduce nuance.  They just tell you the story as you go introducing one rediculous reveal after another.  

The final reveal that the AI is basically your child, and the person behind the murders is also your child, and the internet addict is also your child is just obnoxious.  Although I did enjoy my ending that the AI wants to govern the world to be a very fun cyberpunk ending.  Also because i found the AI the most likeable character in the game, i think the writers wanted the AI to come off as worrisome if not evil, but the whole game i was like man people should just do what this AI tells them it's master plan is clearly the best.  [/spoiler]

So yea, that's Technobabylon, another mediocre adventure game from the studio dedicated to making classic nostalgia adventure games.  Sigh, I feel if they just embraced the modern developments and story telling techniques games like Life is Strange have made they might be able to accomplish something very special, but instead they like to just lie back and copy what has already been done and like the main character in this game they shall always be stuck in the past.  Still, I enjoyed my time with it, just get it on massive sale, or you know just buy Life is Strange the best adventure game ever made.  So #worth $3

28311075.review:
A sci fi point n click adventure straight out of a Gibson novel. I loved every second of it, despite a few puzzle hickups where online walkthroughs had to help me.

Written and directed, created and voiced by only a few, yet on the peek of what can be done in this industry, I would say it´s a masterpiece in it´s own right. Let me further explain why:


[b]Art and Graphics:[/b]

- One of the lesser impressive things are the graphics. You can literally count the pixels because of the pixelart. The unique touch in this game´s visual design lies less in its color scheme or art design but more in the story and characters that it has. It´s not the prettiest at all, clearly a reasoning with the creators budget. It keeps true to the atmopshere and visual response etiquette of such games though and delivers all it needs to for what it wants to achieve in order to suck you into the world.


[b]Technical issues and bugs:[/b]

- Didn´t encounter any bugs in playing this roughly for 19 hrs. Completed. Experienced one issue though, audio controls in the options menu don´t control the speech volume which has to be set through windows audio mixer instead. Naggy but alt tab works easily. Everything else just worked as it should. High quality for the few people that worked on it. 


[b]Story and characters:[/b]

- Now here it all comes together into why it´s such a masterfully crafted game. Not only are all characters shaped with unique and likeable or understandable/reasonable personalities and motives but they also all have their own useful role in a complete story with twists and plots/schemes. The theme of the game builds upon that and combines these characters and the well written dialogues and philosophical scaffolding under the sci fi transhumanistic topic it´s made for with such detailed plotting, it blew me away at times. I literally was blown away each anew that characters in a video game could even be written and thought off as such diverse and well build figures. Usage is smart and they clearly preferred having less useless characters but instead craft a lot well done ones into their storyweb together with good humor and cheeky sarcasm. Love it. You could literally fill a whole wikipage just with this game and create an own universe out of it. Genetics, cannibalism, morals, old vs new standards, transhumanism, synths and robots, consciousness and cloning, gengineering, AI and selfawareness, religious terrorism, nuclear fallout and it´s aftermath, VR, organic computing, etc and much more, it´s all in there to feed the sci fi nerds mind. Psychological and emotional drama with decisions. You also can decide from time to time in certain situations how an outcome will play out. Of couse with different endings too. The game has it all and works like a well oiled machine. It even introduced new stuff I didn´t think of before and made me curious like: Wetware and AI splitting. It leaves you thinking after finishing it. And it will always become a conclusive whole. No stupid hidden secrets, no stupid easter egg story details, old school straight up masterwork of writing. It´s pretty mature with gore and darker topics throughout. No children allowed. Thank god.


[b]Gameplay:[/b]

- Your usual point n click adventure, let´s you think outside the box, combine tools or hack systems with wetware, use CI splitters to swap out modules of personality and memory. Less hammer on nail, but creative stuff where a casual adventurer with no brain for technology will often just trial and error. PnC veterans though will have a smooth and enjoyable non stressful ride. Except for a few situations where the game really was unhelpful in even giving me hints in what to do, I had to get myself some walkthroughs. And those scenes really blew. In total only 3 though. Not much in a game of 10 chapters with 14hrs of gameplay, if you take away my idling and fooding.

Loved every second of it. Get it. Fuck watch dogs, fuck binary domain, ass effect, sci fi is done like this!

28237312.review:
A great ride from start to finish, 'Technobabylon' hits all the right notes both in terms of being a great scifi/cyberpunk tale and as a point an click adventure. The story is tight and paced well, the characters are engaging and well written and the puzzles blend into the plot with general seemlessness.

Not everyone will be on board with the pixel art style and AGS engine (which is frankly starting to show its age even in 'faux-retro' titles like this) but it's hard to complain about stuff like that when it suits the storytelling style so well and there's obviously so much love put into these environments and characters; it's really remarkable what the developers have done within the constraints of the tools they're working with.

I found the difficulty of the puzzles somewhat on the easy side and there was never a point where I had to reach for a walkthrough, but then I'm a genre-veteran. The game pretty sucessfully (and organically) limits inventory and number of spaces to explore, and the characters around you are usually dropping subtle hints in dialouge as to how to proceed which keeps things moving. There's more than one way to solve a number of the challenges too which is a nice touch.

So, if you're looking for something that'll keep you busy for 10-15 hours and maybe spark off a few neurons as you wonder where technology is taking us as a species then you could do a lot worse than take a trip to Newtown in 2087. I feel there's a lot more exploring to be done in this world and I'd love to spend more time with these characters too... sequel? Please? 

On a side note, I'd like to give this game extra-special props for being one of the few games (or pieces of media period) to do representation of minorities in a really great way; two of the PCs are female non-caucasians and a major character is trans. The game and dialouge never hammer any of these points or use them as cheap ways to stir controversy and all come across as individuals. It's really great to see people from many different racial backgrounds and sexual orientations in roles both heroic and villanious and to be able to interact with them without these identifiers being the defining aspects of their characters. Many writers and devs could learn a lot from Technocrat in this area.

28057199.review:
I have to say, Technobablyon is the first point and click adventure I've really enjoyed.

All of the puzzles are SMART. Not just "click random thing on random other things until stuff happens". You can actually THINK about the puzzles, think about what could actually solve them, then work towards those solutions, making for satisfying gameplay!

The characters are also smart! They're different, wrong sometimes, make mistakes, but they actually try to think and understand what is going on. I enjoyed all of the protagonists.

I'm happy to say that every time I got stumped on a puzzle (with one minor exception, mentioned below), it wasn't because the solution was bizarre or counter-intuitive, it was just that I hadn't thought about the actual facts of puzzle the right way.

The major downside is the ending (spoilers).

A minor flaw is it sloppily scripted (lots of weird bugs that you can cause, nothing game-breaking but obviously not been through thorough QA, like the door lock lights disappearing (not turning off - literally disappearing) after you go through the door and return, or Lao being able to hand her wetware to Regis but not get it back).

It's also unclear that there is an entire third floor in the Trance, making the final part of the puzzle a matter of luck or blind guesswork.

But the big part is the endings are unsatisfying. Either you force a person into slavery, or you force them into being someone else's agenda and to go through an invasive mind-altering procedure without their input. I would have been much happier if there was a third option, where you can actually respect the autonomy of the AGI and let it free without compulsion. Or at least if you can ask Central what she thinks of her options.
