27092932.review:
Technobabylon est un bon jeu d'aventure, visuellement très aléatoire. Le meilleur du cyberpunk et du pixel art, les panoramas les plus dingues et quelques tableaux esthétiquement très ambitieux réussiraient presque à nous faire oublier les autres décors ratés, le banal et le cradingue. Un bon quart du jeu se passe d'ailleurs dans une simulation informatique qui nous est décrite comme un deuxième monde fascinant, un Eden de gigaoctets, un univers parallèle fantastique dans lequel des millions d'utilisateurs gâchent leur vie. Un paradis virtuel auquel on a du mal à croire : desservi par des idées vusuelles datées, ce [i]web 3.0[/i] fait peine à voir avec son interface désespérément vide et ses allures de Minitel sous VR.

Le scénario n'est pas si emballant que ça non plus. Le stylo est un peu trop lourd, l'écriture un poil trop facile pour nous surprendre. Technobabylon exagère des rebondissements glauques pour avoir l'air cool ; ses théories correspondent si bien aux peurs dictées par les meilleurs romans d'anticipation qu'il n'a rien trouvé de mieux que de les dépasser dans l'excès pour s'en distinguer ; Technobabylon oublie d'être autre chose qu'un Game of Thrones du futur, une oeuvre qui, à force de vouloir nous montrer à quel point elle peut être sombre, donne l'impression de n'être qu'un adolescent un peu intelligent qui montre à tout-va des captures d'écran du [i]deep web[/i] pour impressionner ses camarades de classe, un récit immature qui ne cherche à choquer que pour choquer. C'est pourtant au milieu de cette débauche souvent inutile que Technobabylon est paradoxalement le plus intéressant : cette vision [i]forcément![/i] dystopique du lendemain a le mérite de confronter les élans d'aujourd'hui aux chutes qui les attendent, met le doigt sinon sur les excès, sur la dynamique de notre société qui ne cherche à violer ses tabous que pour le simple plaisir de se féliciter d'avoir pu le faire. Les justifications morales qui nous encombraient disparaissent, la bêtise et l'égoïsme peuvent briller de tout leur éclat. Comme dans un concours de pipi télévisé où on jubile jaune d'être regardé par le monde entier, la seule satisfaction est d'être allé plus loin que les autres.

Technobabylon n'est pas un bon thriller ; il raconte une enquête dont on comprend les aboutissants trop vite. Mais il est un bon point & click aux énigmes logiques quoi qu'un brin inattendues. Divisée en dix actes, l'aventure claque et verrouille chacune des portes que l'on passe ; impossible de revenir sur les tableaux des chapitres précédents. L'aire de jeu (et donc des puzzles) est limitée et évite ainsi les écueils d'une progression labyrinthique. Les rares énigmes farfelues sont compensées par cette progression parfaitement délimitée. Parce qu'il nous pousse toujours en avant, Technobabylon est un chemin sans impasses.

Technobabylon est parfois maladroit, souvent trop absolu. Mais il n'est avare de rien ; le background est documenté, le gameplay tire profit des trois héros à incarner, tous les dialogues sont doublés et le sont très bien - si on accepte d'oublier un personnage français qui ne sait pas parler français. C'est une histoire aux grosses ficelles qui arrive quand même à être touchante ; c'est un récit bavard qui dit tout ce qui lui passe par la tête, une aventure qui a beaucoup de choses à montrer et à suggérer. Les conséquences d'un monde où les enfants ne s'amusent qu'à dépasser les lignes rouges tracées par leurs parents. L'une des destinations potentielles d'une logique qui veut aller toujours plus loin, toujours plus haut, toujours plus vite. L'accident possible d'une civilisation, comme ce train sur le point de dérailler ou cet atlhlète aveugle qui fonce à toute allure dans une vierge de fer. Un jeu qui fait déjà passer les végétaliens et les [i]genderfluids[/i] pour des vieux réactionnaires.

(Mais Gemini Rue était vachement mieux)

26743014.review:
TLDR: If you dislike  point-and-clickers for their endless backtracking, vague or even nonsensical puzzles, and/or "jokes>story" attitude, give Technobabylon a shot. 

The game is almost constantly moving forward, with little need to return to areas previously visited; puzzles are logical and straightforward yet challenging, and your goal in any given situation is clear; and excellent writing means you experience an engaging story with developed characters while still getting to enjoy a traditional sci-fi setting, with more than a little humour thrown in. Technobabylon proves that the problems asscociated with most point-and-click adventures aren't an indelible part of the genre.

26742782.review:
So when I finished Kathy Rain, I was left feeling greatly dissatisfied with the story and only liking maybe 3 characters from the entire game. The mechanics were good enough, though, so I figured I'd give Technobabylon a go since it had a similar "look" to it in terms of having the appearance of a '90s adventure game. When the game loaded, I saw that the same publisher made the game, and I immediately felt my heart sink, because Kathy Rain put me out so badly, and when Technobabylon started, its gameplay mechanics were obviously not as streamlined as Kathy Rain's, having less interaction options, less stuff to interact with on each screen, less mandatory dialog, and interactive stuff did not show on the screen when pushing a button like in Kathy Rain (spacebar). Technobabylon was going to be a techno-turd...or so I thought.

Instead, I found a game with far more relevant characters, likable characters (for me, at least), legitimate antagonists (screw you, Crimson Man from Kathy Rain!), and a story and world that were quite intriguing. It's a cyberpunk setting where a large city has had an AI put in charge of all of its civil services, and a couple of your characters you control are officers of the law, who report to the AI, dealing with manhunts, homicide, etc. The guy has a nice character arc, the gal is just plain likable, and another female you play as gives you the impression in her first 30 seconds of self-narrated introduction that she's going to be one thing, then you really see what's going on right after and realize her opinion of herself and the reality are quite different, and makes for an interesting character.

As a cop of the world, you will be mostly dealing with physical things in the world, with a stun gun and standard adventure game puzzle-solving. However, as the one girl, you enter the "TRANCE," which is basically The Matrix/TRON. Users have digital avatars and can interact online with one another. Due to the plot, you'll do very little of interacting with other users, except at one point in the game. Most of the time, however, you will be rubbing blue gel on machines to establish a connection between them and you, letting you interact with comical artificial intelligences to try to resolve problems that would otherwise be impossible for her to overcome in the real world. It's a nice spin to have the game change things up in this fashion.

The introductions of characters are informative and there are a fair number of surprises in terms of certain characters showing up again who seemed like a one-time thing, much to my delight. My favorite character was practically a gag character, but was in the game sporadically until the end. No amazing villains, but they're pretty decent; one's a bit of an eye-roll-inducer (for me, anyway). This world is just pretty cool. It "borrows" a lot from stuff like TRON/The Matrix/Shadowrun (a character even calls the real world the "meatspace," but it still felt like an original story, with plenty of dressing of things that weren't crucial to the main plot but did wonders for world-building. 

The puzzles made me think much of the time, though there were times I was clicking on things at random if I got stuck. I managed to avoid using a walkthrough except ONE time. It was literally the final puzzle I had left to solve in the game (involved some glowing lights on a wall that I couldn't find). The difficulty of the game was nice and had less rage-inducing puzzles than Kathy Rain did, and it didn't feel so "anal" as Kathy rain in regard to having to go through every piece of dialog to proceed (though I did because the world, story, and characters interested me).

I would love to see more games in this world, but in different cities and with new and returning characeters. Heck, I'll just admit it: I loved Cheffie. I think we're suppose to hate her or be annoyed by her, but man was she fun for me. Anywho, I think sequels or prequels set in different parts of the world not strongly connected to each storyline could be excellent, and I would love to see them get made. I definitely recommend this game to fans of cyberpunk and/or point-and-click adventure games.

Si buscas una aventura gráfica cuya historia te enganche, que te traiga un ambiente cyberpunk - blade runner muy cuidado y depurado, que te haga revivir la nostalgia de las aventuras clásicas ... Technobabylon sin duda es una gran opción. Desde el primer momento te das cuenta que estás ante un producto que respeta esa filosofía y te incita a tratar de ir resolviendo sus puzzles.
Interfaz muy depurada, simplista rayando lo minimalista pero para qué más, huye de los tópicos fáciles como las colecciones de elementos, los interminables menús con opciones y más opciones... mirar, usar, combinar. Y ya está, no necesitas más... aunque no por ello es un juego sencillo, sus puzzles te atascarán más de una vez pero su dificultad está bastante bien balanceada para no desesperarte, al menos en lo que llevo jugado.
El gran CONTRA que tiene el juego, es que al menos en su edición inicial sólo está en inglés. Seguramente con un par de búsquedas en google se localice un parche para su traducción
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=803802425

26714067.review:
Technobabylon est un jeu indé point and click futuriste avec des graphismes en pixel-art qui raconte l'histoire de différents personnages qui vont être amenés à se croiser et qui vont devoir coopérer afin de sauver la ville de Newton dans les années 2080.

On pourrait résumer ainsi ce qu'est Technobabylon mais on passerait alors à côté de cette perle vidéoludique méconnue d'une grande majorité de gamers ! Je dois avouer que j'ai été bluffé par ce jeu indépendant qui est tout bonnement magnifique ! :D

Tout d'abord, l'histoire du jeu est très soignée et le background des personnages permet une immersion en tout points dans l'univers de Technobabylon ! Vous incarnez successivement Latha, une enfant des rues devenue accro à la réalité virtuelle que l'on peut qualifier de "Thrall" c'est-à-dire qui passe toute sa vie connectée (elle ne se déconnecte que pour s'alimenter ou lorsque le réseau, le "Trance" est en panne), le Dr Regis qui est un agent du CEL (une police criminelle de pointe si vous préférez) ainsi que Max Lao, hackeuse de génie / ancienne criminelle repentie, désormais elle est la partenaire du Dr Régis.

Il faut noter que le jeu est en anglais, il faut donc maîtriser la langue de Shakespeare si vous désirez vivre pleinement l'expérience humaine et philosophique que vous propose Technobabylon ! ;-)

Les graphismes ainsi que la direction artistique sont très soignées et nous font vite oublier que nous avons affaire à du pixel-art, les dialogues favorisent également le sentiment d'immersion que j'évoquais tout à l'heure avec un scénario riche en rebondissements !

Point très important : le gameplay ; celui-ci est très fourni et suffisamment varié pour que l'on ne s'ennuie pas !
Vous pourrez ainsi mener une investigation sur une scène de crime toute fraîche qui s'enchaîne avec une course poursuite parsemée d'obstacles qui sont autant de puzzles à résoudre ! Vous pourrez aussi participer à une sorte de cluedo grandeur nature bref je n'en dis pas plus par peur de vous spoiler ! :-)
Cependant, je dois reconnaître que parfois certains passages sont plus ardus que d'autres et nécessitent soit un sens de l'observation très développé soit l'utilisation d'un guide pour se débloquer d'un petit casse-tête où l'on reste plusieurs minutes bloqué alors qu'une simple succession de quelques actions suffit à avancer dans le chapitre !
Encore une fois, je ne trouve pas que c'est un problème puisque les puzzles restent très cohérents et logiques contrairement à d'autres jeux point and click et qu'un excellent guide existe à ce sujet qui vous permettra d'avancer sans craintes de vous faire spoiler ! :D

Enfin, le rapport qualité prix est excellent étant donné que le jeu est souvent en soldes et qu'il possède cartes à échanger et succès steam !

Je le recommande donc vivement à tous !
Technobabylon propose une expérience riche et unique qui fait réfléchir et c'est suffisamment rare pour le souligner ici !

26628059.review:
Cyberpunk went on the decline when it became a series of tropes and not a speculative framework. Too much of it became dressed-up from the 1980s, when the internet itself was beyond the awareness or comprehension of most people.

Technobabylon doesn't do that. It *gets* cyberpunk and develops it with an understanding of existing technology, developments on the cusp of existence, and the way states and capital shape how that technology affects our lives. Rather than trying to spin virtual reality as some barely imagined new concept like William Gibson never existed, Technobabylon looks at biotech, AI development, and automation to flesh out a world that feels incredibly plausible and compelling.

Puzzle systems are never insanely "out there," but there are fun applications of some mechanics. The AI Splitter that lets you dismantle and rebuild AI minds with different pieces of each other really stands out as one of the more fun ones. And a few obnoxious pixel-hunts notwithstanding, puzzles in Technobabylon feel largely fair and coherent.

On the whole this is one of the best titles Wadjet Eye has published to date. Absoltely worth a go for cyberpunk fans and adventure gamers alike.

Una sencilla aventura gráfica de corte futurista cyberpunk distópica.

Está dividida en capítulos pequeños autocontenidos, de forma que el nº de objetos disponibles para completar los puzzles suele ser bastante limitado, y las pantallas a recorrer no suelen ascender a más de 3 o 4.

La historia es correcta, no siempre manejamos al mismo personaje por lo que se cuenta a trozos, inconexos al principio y se van atando cabos. Hay algún giro de guión que otro, aunque se ven venir.

Hay algunas partes que requieren de pixel hunting, en general me he quedado atascado más veces por faltarme un objeto o elemento de interacción que por no saber qué hacer (lo cual no quita que también haya habido de las otras). En resumen, una aventura gráfica correcta en todos los sentidos, sin mucho más que destacar.

26495812.review:
Technobabylon is a traditional point and click set in a sci-fi setting. It plays like a detective story where you are trying to find out clues as to what exactly is going on and you discover the plot of the story piece by piece.

The puzzles are not too hard and most can be figured out by some trial and error. However as with every point and click there might be one that gets you, luckily there seem to be quite a few walkthroughs available on the internet for when you get stuck. 

A big plus for this particular point and click is that almost all the text is voiceacted and there are a bunch of bonus voice acted lines you would not even expect. So props to the developer for that.

I personally enjoyed the story quite a bit and would recommend this game as one of the better point and clicks ive played.

26494034.review:
Technobabylon is a throw back to the classic point and click adventure games of the mid 1990s. If you were a fan of the classics like the original Monkey Island or Sam & Max then this game will be for you. In blocky 16 bit graphics the cyberpunk world comes to life with a great story, interesting characters and cool scenes.

The game wisely keeps you locked in 'chapter' areas meaning you dont need to scratch your head picking up a random object in one scene only to use it 10 scenes later, all objects are useable pretty much in the same area you find them.

Dialogue is tight and well written, voice narration is solid and story in general is interesting and engaging.

However, one MAJOR gripe I have with this game, and it REALLY bothered me on too many occasions was how unclear interactable objects were!! The times I got stuck and had to google how to move forward ALWAYS resulted in me having just missed a chest of drawers or a cupboard and had nothing to do with actually getting stuck on a puzzle. It ended up with me on each new scene running the mouse up and down the screen ensuring I had 'scanned' everywhere in fear of missing an interactable object. Some sort of 'highlighting' system is sorely missed.

All in all a solid point & click adventure set in a cool cyper punk world.

26472595.review:
I picked this game up on Humble Bundle with some others because it looks interesting and I enjoy deduction style games.
But I was very surprised that this game was worth MORE than every penny I paid. I was worried that this game might actually be selling itself too short! So I checked the store page and saw $15. Trust me, this game is WORTH $15. I am about 7 chapters into the game and I love it. 

Buy this game if you enjoy the following:

-Sci-fi action drama stories
-Deductive shows/games/movies
-Wonderfully well done 16bit style art.
-A challenge

This game will have you stuck sometimes for a while which I found surprising. A lot of point and click puzzle games are very straight forward or use some cheap tactics to try and throw you off. This game is very genuine. You have to think and I found myself having to take breaks instead of binging on a game because I found myself stuck on a chapter that I just couldn't piece together. 

This game does not hide interactable items and objects from you. You won't find yourself saying "wow really, they hid this super important thing here where no one can see it?". This game gives you everything you need right infront of you. All you have to do is figure out what to do. It's less of a Where's Waldo type of point and click and more of a real deductive mystery.

There will be times where you get frustrated and can't figure things out because the puzzles are tough, but like Dark Souls, when you figure it out the feeling of satisfaction is absolutely worth it.

26465610.review:
With the high amount of positive reviews, I wanted to point out some of the flaws of this game that made it hard for me to truly enjoy it. It is not bad, and the pixelated graphics give nice retro feel to the whole experience, while telling a futuristic cyberpunk story. Some of the characters were nice to follow. Some puzzles could be solved in a few ways, unlocking different achievements. Overall I kept playing this game, which is enough of a reason to say it can be enjoyable.

There always will be a 'but' at some point that changes the whole statement, right?

Well, as I said, some characters are interesting to follow. However, the story switches between three main ones, with short flashbacks where we follow side ones. The voiceover on some of them is bad, and one of the main characters sounds so awfully unnatural I was at some point considering quitting the otherwise interesting plot.

The switching between MCs points of view is probably intended to show variety of classic cyberpunk landscapes. Expensive apartments, rundown basements, abandoned factories, sprinkly-clean laboratories, neon skyscrapers etc etc., all the while mentioning stuff that cyberpunk is most known for. Global corporations, cloning, gen. engineering, all-powerful AI, androids, cyborgs, virtual reality, loss of identity, background brutal warfare etc. Nothing of that sounds particularly new. There are some new, sometimes amusing ideas, but they are wasted with overwhelming majority of the usual.

The animation. oh boy. Pixelated graphics have their appeal, which i personally enjoy, yet they are so badly animated for some characters, you'd think this game is not really retro, but 20 years old. Maybe that's the idea. I wouldn't mind, but while all character's close-up portraits are nice, as are most sceneries and animations, some fail horribly. Two of the MCs look like they were made with MS Paint. Graphics range from eye-catching to blocky gibberish pixelgore.


Okay, I am proud of you if you managed to read it up to this point. So I'll just make my opinion short: don't buy this game for full price, it's not worth if you're into indie retro ones. But if your friend shares it to you, or you buy it in a bundle, play it, it's actually enjoyable, even if a bit too plain.

26465470.review: La scena indie ha provato a rinverdire il genere delle avventure grafiche per anni, ma i giochi che possano davvero dirsi riusciti sono pochini: Technobabylon è uno dei migliori che io abbia giocato in questo decennio. Gli enigmi sono sensati e di difficoltà ragionevole. La sceneggiatura prevede una narrazione non lineare che riesce a tenere alto l'interesse fino alla fine. L'ambientazione cyberpunk è gestita bene, molta roba già vista e scippata di qua e di là ma con un'attenzione particolare alle questioni etico-morali (questo futuro è oggettivamente l'incubo di Adinolfi). La grafica anni 90 funziona benissimo così come le animazioni. Due finali entrambi ben scritti. Che altro volete? L'ho pagato un misero dollaro grazie all'humble bundle e mi sembra davvero di avere commesso un furto.

26458983.review: Really good adventure game. The cyber future set up with wetware and bio computers is pretty sweet.

26458062.review:
Nie spodziewałem się, że pixelartowy indyk może w tym roku stanąć na podium razem z Wiedźminem, ale tak się stało. Patrząc na listę ukończonych przez mnie gier, muszę powiedzieć, że obok Dzikiego Gonu jest to najlepsza gra w jaką grałem w 2016 i udało się jej pobić kilka tytułów klasy AAA.

Złożyło się na to kilka czynników. Jest to gra ze zdecydowanie najlepszym scenariuszem (tak, lepszym niż Wiedźmin), który jest wprost fenomenalny. Writing dorównuje najlepszym powieściom sci-fi, a setting to esencja cyberpunku z zakręconymi, szokującymi, ale i w całkiem realnymi pomysłami - jeśli ekstrapolujemy obecny stan nauki i wyobrazimy sobie co mogłoby być za ponad dwieście lat. Nie chcę niczego spoilować, najlepiej samemu zagrać. Świat przedstawiony jest spójny i interesujący, przez całą grę dowiadujemy się czegoś nowego i poznajemy kolejne smaczki. Miłym dodatkiem są newsy, które zmieniają się podczas gry.

Zagadki są logiczne, nie ma łączenia małpy z batyskafem, wszystko ma sens i działa tak jak się tego spodziewamy. Zaciąłem się trzy razy na chwilę, ale nigdy na tyle, żeby sięgnąć po solucję. Gameplayowo jest to również jedna z lepszych przygodówek w jakie grałem. Zdecydowanie najwyższa półka. Co ciekawe, gra posiada po kilka rozwiązań do niektórych zagadek, przez co zawiera pewną dozę nieliniowości - rzecz raczej niespotykana w przygodówkach point & click.

Na uwagę zasługuje świetne udźwiękowienie - zarówno muzyka jak i odgłosy - ale przede wszystkim - rewelacyjny voice acting, w niczym nie ustępujący największym produkcjom, a niektóre wręcz przebijający o kilka długości. W całej grze nie ma ani jednego niepasującego głosu, czy aktora czytającego z kartki. Takich bajerów się nie spodziewałem po grze stworzonej w Adventure Game Studio.

Grafika, mimo wszechobecnej pikselozy i niskiej rozdzielczości, jest ładna.

Gromkie brawa dla panów z Technocrat i Wadjet Eye Games.

26408022.review:
I picked this up on the Humble Gems Bundle, and it indeed a hidden gem that I am glad to have picked up.

I haven't played a point-and-click adventure game in quite a while, but this was a good foray back into that territory.  The setting and writing was very enjoyable, the art excellent, and the music immersive.  But the main point of this kind of adventure is exploring the story, which requires a good story to be a good game.  Technobabylon doesn't disappoint me here.

As someone interested in the virtual, metaverses, etc, I was on board immediately with the concept that the Trance provided, and other sci-fi concepts (such as gengineering) had enough grounding in modern science to give a bit of a "This could be the future" edge.  But it's not all dark, gritty, and brooding.  There is a LOT of dialog to explore, and there were quite a few moments I laughed out loud, mostly due to AI personalities (Turret + Cheffie = absolutely hilarious)

The puzzles were largely simple for me to figure out, and the only places I got stuck and had to look online for help were when I was missing something entirely -- it's not so bad you could call it pixel-hunting, but you still need to be thorough if you find yourself getting stuck.  Death is handled in a forgiving manner, simply rewinding back to a state just before you died if you did something foolish.

I ended up playing through this twice -- the second time with commentary and to pick up 100% achievements -- and I bought a copy for my sister and recommended it to a friend.  I'd recommend it for anyone who enjoys point-and-click adventure types, cyberpunk settings, and have a taste for automeals served by an AI so cheerful it should be criminal.

Overall play time for both runs was ~20 hours for me. Given my second run was much faster, I'd say you're probably looking at a 10 to 15 hour experience. That may not seem like much, but it was a very enjoyable time, and I've put more hours into games and got less out of them in the past, so I'd say it was worth it.

Also, I want that "nom nom nom" sound, and I don't know why.

I feel like my previous review didn't do this masterpiece any justice so Im gonna write a new one.

My all time favorite genre is Cyberpunk, and there aren't that many Cyberpunk games out there. I have played most of them and some of them stuck in my mind, others disappeared quickly. Technobabylon is one of those games who have stuck in my mind.
The setting of the game is perfect, a dystopian large city controlled by some big force, and lots of high tech (hence the perfect quote "High Tech, Low Life"). The characters are very likeable and interesting, and the story is great as well. If you have played Gemini Rue, which is also sort of Cyberpunk, I can say that this game delivers on a much larger scale.

It took me around 9 hours to finish the game, and I took my time interacting with everything and getting stuck on difficult puzzles. I had to use walkthroughs for some of the puzzles, but it's nothing too extreme. The soundtrack is in my opinion of the best aspects of the game, pin-pointing the dystopian setting.

I give this game a 10/10, since I liked every aspect of it, and because it totally nails my vision of a perfect Cyberpunk future

26299564.review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Technobabylon
[b]Developer:[/b]  Technocrat Games
[b]Publisher:[/b]  Wadjet Eye Games
[b]Genre:[/b]  2D adventure

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
While I’m no self proclaimed fan of pixel graphics in modern video games, there was something that drew me towards Technobablylon. Perhaps it was the fusion between cyberpunk and neo-noir genres and the similarities I could observe between this game and one of my favorite movies of all time, Blade Runner. Technobabylon has an intriguing plot of its own, which I won’t spoil but I can assure it that it is quite original and this time, you’re actually getting your money’s worth. There were a few instances which required that you return to a previously “swept” area and use the newly acquired itmes in your inventory. I’m not a fan of backtracking in general but at least there weren’t many such situations. The point & click interface runs smoothly but it took some tinkering with the game’s graphical settings before I was satisfied with the result and the dialogue font is a bit pixeated for my taste but it wasn’t that much of a strain. On the other hand, the  soundtrack truly stands out and the many commentaries (on each scene and on some interactions) from the developer and publisher, reveled just how important this project has been to them. I respect that. All in all, you’re in for a decently lengthy adventure, should you choose to give Technobabylon a try. It really has few flaws and I hope we may see a sequel to it one day.

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Excellent storyline.
+ Beautiful art style and tech-noir setting.
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.
+ In-game commentaries from the dev team.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Some puzzles involve backtracking to a previous scene.

[b]Rating 8/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Cubbes]Cubbes[/url].[/quote]

26294667.review:
Хороший, олдскульный поинт-энд-клик квест. Дух киберпанка передан  блестяще, но к сожалению ближе к развязке сюжет начинает плыть: если вы знакомы «Нейромантом» Гибсона, то во второй половине игры вас начинает преследовать чувство, что вы  это уже где-то видели. В итоге, вместо заимствований у Гибсона, игра начинает  бесстыдно копировать целые куски и сюжетные повороты из книги, что не является преступлением, но на оригинальность не тянет. 

При этом, игра умудряется сохранить индивидуальность во многом благодаря атмосфере и персонажам. Герои получились сложными и интересными. Один из них на протяжении большей части игры не вызывал у меня ничего кроме отвращения и раздражения, пока я не понял, что наркоман в ломке и не может быть обаятельным и интересным. Другой оказался... не совсем тем, чем казался (ох, без спойлеров не просто) и это привело... к интересной динамике в отношениях между главными героями. 

Графика, как это и свойственно проектам от Wadjet Eye выполнена крупным пикселем и выглядит здорово, хотя текст читается с трудом. С художественной точки зрения дизайн выдержан бесподобно- высокие, холодные небоскребы, яркие неоновые вывески, вечная ночь, все на месте. 

Загадки тоже принадлежат к старой школе и не отличаются логичностью и простотой. В этом, пожалуй, заключается одна из главных проблем игры: головоломки не работают на сюжет и не продвигают историю, а скорее служат препятствием, лишь преодолев которое, удаётся вернуться к повествованию. 

В целом, Техновавилон- отличная игра, красивый и умный киберпанковский квест с интересными персонажами и увлекательной, хотя и немного шаблонной историей.

26255501.review:
I'm not much for point and clicks-- I only got this off a humble bundle. But I stuck through to the end and finished it it  two sessions. It turns out I really liked it.

The main pros: 
• The story is great. An immense amount of thought went into background details about the universe. I feel like I know things about the place that these characters live.
• The voice acting is well done.
• The characters are likeable, but flawed. They're human-like.
• Most of the puzzles are intuitive and well-considered. They often offer multiple approaches.
• The sci-fi science is believable-- and chilling.

The main cons:
• The game often tries to put the characters in urgent situations that would demand immediate action, then asks you to solve a multi-room puzzle that involves backtracking across the map. Pacing is entierly thrown out the window.
• The art style of the characters is dramatically different from the enviornments. And a lot rougher. The result is a disconnect between the actors and the scene.
• A fair few of the puzzles rely on obscure 'find the hidden object' solutions. Not all of them-- but more than enough to distinctly annoy you.

25181812.review:
Pese al aspecto cutre y tosco de gráficos pixelados, un juego excelentemente escrito, con diferentes opciones para resolver puzzles, personajes bien construídos, buen doblaje, muy buena ambientación y sobre todo algo difícil de conseguir en juegos de este tipo: la sensación de inmersión y la coherencia del mundo en que transcurre la historia.

 Una historia de investigación e intriga ambientada en un futuro donde una IA controla toda la vigilancia, mantenimiento y seguridad de una ciudad independiente al estilo ciudad-estado. Con pocos recursos y buenos textos descriptivos, Technobabylon hace posible imaginar a la perfección cómo funciona el día a día y cómo es la realidad del mundo, tanbto en la ciudad de Newton como fuera. Un cruce de influencias entre Ghost in the Shell y Neuromante, encajado en una investigación criminal.

 El juego trae comentarios de los desarrolladores de forma opcional, finales alternativos y un producto muy bien acabado de buena duración y buen ritmo. Un juego de los que ponen a los creadores (Technocrate) en el punto de mira de cara a lo siguiente que saquen.

25125683.review:
The Wadjet Eye legacy continues with yet another interesting addition to their innovative point and click adventure game lineup: Technobabylon. Set in a dystopian future (they sure do love that aesthetic) of quarreling nation-states with drastically different governments, you play a pair of detectives, and an unlikely accomplice, in a futuristic city known as Newton. The city is under threat by a mysterious character known as the mindjacker who steals peoples’ minds for unknown reasons and you are tasked with bringing him to justice. 

Typical for Wadjet Eye, this game offers a new interactive system to spice things up called ‘wetware’, wherein the user can connect wirelessly with people or systems allowing the player to solve puzzles via interactions in an abstract parallel world known as the Trance (e.g. cyberspace). Eventually you also gain the ability to manipulate artificial intelligence entities, called synths, through special programs that control their personalities.

The environments in Technobabylon are much more constrained than those in other adventure games by this studio which has a slight side effect of making a good number of the puzzles easier to solve since you don’t have as many rooms to cycle through and consequently less items to interact with as well. Seasoned PnC adventure game veterans might be turned off a bit by this aspect but I found that the story and consequence system (as well as the alternate ending) make up for it. The game is also very dialogue heavy but the majority of it is well-spent and you will find yourself learning more about characters and the world surrounding them instead of feeling like you’re wasting your time.

In an era where AAA studios are pumping out non-stop schlock, it’s refreshing to see a title like Technobabylon that bucks the trend and delivers a great experience at the same time. It’s definitely worth the $15 and even more of a steal if you manage to catch it on sale.

24322161.review:
It's a good game, but I don't recommend it. How's that possible? Let me explain.

I don't much care for puzzles in point and click games – some people call them illogical, some absurd, some charmingly crazy. For me they're fun, although, in this particular case, I had to peek into a walkthrough a couple of times because I've missed some almost-pixel-size items. The point is – gameplay contains everything you would expect from this genre. And it's OK.

My reservation concern the most important element of the game – the story. There are no good characters in „Technobabylon”. By good I mean morally good, not well written. There is a struggle at the top of the food chain between overly controlling cyberpunky-antiutopian AI and a bunch of plutocrats/oligarchs. We see debauchery, hypocrisy, hubris and greed all around. Even our protagonists aren't really characters to root for. One of them is an internet junkie (or, to be precise, trance junkie, futuristic VR version of the internet), who's addicted to information stream, bright colour-flickering images bombarding senses, for whom real world is too slow and too demanding; other one being an ex-bioengineer who used to make suicide bombers, a pro-eugenics scientist, shady (at best) in bioethics field, now a good ol' grumpy cop.

I was getting further and further into the story, yet getting more and more impatient that there is no person in the game's world who I wanted to succeed. And then it hit me. It's exactly how it supposed to be. After all the title of the game is „TechnoBABYLON” – it's supposed to be a moral depravity feast. But the plot missed something, something crucial for this type of story. It missed it's „idiot”, it's good guy, it's Shatov (Comparing „Technobabylon” to Dostoyevsky is unfair, but his works, in this case especially „Demons”, are a good example of stories exploring demoralized circles).

I understand that the creators' vision is a depressing one. But do I need to spend a few hours watching multitude of ways in which humans can be bad? I know they can be evil, I'm one of them. The game shows a world filled with decadence, but I may as well look out the window. And may even be surprised what I'll found. Even if you think that goodness can't prevail or is naive – show it. Create a character like Simon from „Lord of the Flies” and show him fail. You can argue that our main heroes are trying to do some good, but actually they're just trying to get out of trouble they got in during the course of the plot (still, Regis is getting „redemption arc” at the very end).

If you just want to relax after a day of hard work, you'll be satisfied. Characters are likeable, pacing is all right and pixel-arty environments are quite pretty. My problem is, that beyond that the game touches an interesting topic –  bioethics – but doesn't have anything clever to say about it.

23611164.review:
Traditional pointn'click still has its charm, when it comes with a well-developed story and  interesting, well-integrated puzzles. Wadjet Eye's releases have proven that point time and again. Luckily, Technobabylon is no exception. It is not the first dystopia in the publisher's books (that would be Gemini Rue, and later they have released the post-apocalyptic Primordia), but it might very well be their best one.
The technosceptical story builds a world that at its best moments is at par with William Gibson's Neuromancer and treads similar grounds concerning AIs, digital life, life in the digital and autoritarian societies. And yet, all this heady social critique does not become moralizing grouchiness. The multi-plot narration - done with very competent voice-acting for all dialogue- keeps players engaged with interesting, deep characters and some nicely staged twists (though admittedly some are not as twisty as the writers obviously thought them to be).
The puzzles are exceptionally well done, notwithstanding one or two lesser specimen. No spoilers here, but should you get stuck in a kitchen, you'll know what I mean. But all of them are fitting with the characters and the plot; there is nothing haphazardly glued into the game to bolster playtime, no lazy logic puzzles, not much walking around and no backtracking. Top notch design!
I only played it a year after release, but I have to say that all the laurels Technobabylon gathered in 2015 were well-earned. Definitively one of the best adventure games 2015/16!

23537179.review:
Wadjet Eye publishes yet another great point-and-click adventure game!

This part of this game that sets it apart from others is a VERY well realized semi-near futuristic setting, similar to Ghost in the Shell in its focus on the internet (and opting to go the route of nanomachines rather than cybernetics).  A lot of its dystopian themes seem very plausibly real and dont stray too much into the realm of science fantasy to break my suspension of disbelief.  Add on top of that some very well acted characters (Charlie and Max specifically) and villains, a heavy plot that balances itself very well without overdoing it, and you have a great game.  

There is also a nuanced influence of dialogue choices that impact the game's responses and dialogue without going the route of being an aparrent and forced good-neutral-bad ending choice factor, while still feeling relevant to the story.  I liked it.  If there's anything I disliked, its that Latha's character felt too one dimensional and tangential to the rest of the story, and that her specific sections involving using the web were lacking a robust realization like the rest of the setting.  I forgive them though, since most all other stories in the near-future scifi genre haven't come up with a really robust way to depict a brain-to-machine immersive version of the internet.

Puzzles and mechanics-wise, the game is solid.  As always there is 'that one puzzle' that necessitates a guide, but that is always true of the genre and is not something I look down upon.  There are failstates, but only in a few specific points of the game.  Be warned, some of the scenes in the game can be particularly gruesome and unpleasant to watch (namely the flashback scene with [spoiler]the maidservant gynoid violently disembowling its hallucinating owner after he kills his spouse[/spoiler]), but they are treated with severity and not present to glorify the gruesomeness of the act.

Altogether the game runs about 10 hours if my playtime on steam is accurate.  I enjoyed this game a lot, I'd recommend it.

23526797.review: Excellent writing, story, art, voice acting and puzzles.  Quite possibly the best point and click adventure game I have ever played.

23519893.review: Best point and click game I've played since The Secret of Monkey Island. Awesome writing, all lines are voice acted. 23460570.review:
Being something of an old-time adventure game veteran and and old-fart literary buff I'm conflicted about what to say on  Technobablyon. I've also often found that people are easily impressed by mediocre fare in just about anything, so me saying something is "passable" could mean it's the best thing you've ever seen in your life. That really depends on what you're used to more than anything. Having said that:

The episodic format shows.The game kind-sort-of felt as if it wasn't made as a cohesive whole, and that individual "episodes"  were too "tight" to really let you soak in the atmosphere. Which is a shame, as there was plenty of atmosphere, and the individual epozodes were rather good overall.

However, it did feet like it was going out of it's way to put the player in one "room escape" scenario after another. The overall plot was a bit too grand which made various things feel a bit too drastic. It seems to have elements in place, so to speak, for large multi-plot games like, say, Discworld: Noir, but it turns out to not really be that kind of game. I guess the plot feels strangely  linear, because the game has the old style grapics groove going on, but lacks a central semi-non-linear "open world" item chase chapter that's a staple of the old non-episodic classics. Making one of those is a nightmare, and it would've made the game twice as long, but the game felt like it needed more time to develop it's various characters, and more space to disperse it's dialogue, world-building and commentary in. For a game which makes dialogue so fun and easy to perform and enjoy, it doesn't really do enough with the dialogue because secondary characters are either villains or only there for one scene.

For example, I feel the "comm" feature was an incredible idea, one that's probably been kicking around many point-and-click and detective game enthusiasts heads. Except it's hardly ever used in the most obvious way it would be used in most games - to cut the time it takes to walk around various locations when you just want to talk to a character. I can think of dozens of games that feature would've made much better than they were (many of them classics). In this game it's usability is severely limited because the game lacks that central faux open-world part. Big props to to the person who went and put that into their game, finally, as it might influence someone else to put it in a game that makes more use out of it. Heck, you could take all the shooty / RPG bits out of Fallout 2, rewrite it as a straight point-and-click / dialogue thing, add that feature to the radio so that you can contact folks over distance, and you'd be rolling in money.

Which is to say there's some really good stuff here. The android related puzzles were impossibly cool, the actual "investigation" episode was also very cool, there's great stuff all over the place. But there are also a few too many instances of characters being able to perform certain actions without the actions making sense at the time. I think I just stumbled onto the solutions to many puzzles, and at times I was stuck because I didn't realize certain actions could even be performed, so I would be lacking a step in an otherwise logical sequence of moves. This might mean that a few things had a step-or-two too many, and for this, I blame the episodic format again - if actions required to accomplish something didn't have to all involve so discreet scenations the flow would be much better.

I've heard complaints about the graphics from folks who can't appreciate symbolic art over "realism". I've mixed feelings about it. I'm not necessarily in love with the pixels, as I found the recent remasterings of Lucas Arts stuff quite fine, and I did at times feel like this game could've benefited from a bit more resolution. I wasn't sure it would benefit from more "realism" that would end up creating - the gory bits, and there ARE gory bits, would've stood out more, and the naive bits, and there ARE naive bits, would have stood out more, too. Since pacing makes certain plot related things a bit jarring, more detailed graphics wouldn't have necessarily helped there. Plus, quite a bunch of the art is gorgeous.

Now, most of this soounds like criticism, but when you get down to it, I've not really played a more ambitious point-and-clicker that actually delivered as much as Technobabylon did in quite a while. It did more for me on the cyberpunk front than the Shadowrun games, too. I feel like the folks who made it deserve their money, and that the game isn't really dissapointing as much as it stimulates the player to think about how would they have done it better afterwards. Which is a great thing.

I recommend.

23051552.review:
[h1][i]如果你是解谜游戏爱好者，又喜欢像素风，且对科幻类型感兴趣，那么这款游戏绝对合你胃口。[/i][/h1]
[i]其实[url=http://store.steampowered.com/search/?publisher=Wadjet%20Eye%20Games]Wadjet Eye Games[/url]的游戏都特别合我胃口:P[/i]

由于当初通关是急着写指南，测评方面就隔着，今天突然想起来才特地补上，我就简单摘要点写写吧。

[h1]优：[/h1]
+ 宏大的科幻世界观
+ 语言十分有特色，比如wetware、trance等，还有女主常说的"doom it"
+ 剧情悬念设置到位
+ 谜题难度大体适中，而且可以有不同的解法
+ 许多剧情都有可选分支，但实际上不会对结局造成太大变动
+ 对话全程语音
+ 游戏对话或场景时不时地加入中文要素使华人玩家觉得会有亲切感

[h1]劣：[/h1]
- 没有中文，部分谜题要求英文水平过硬才能解开
- 启动游戏时，有时候鼠标会悬停在画面中间，无法移动，只能关掉重开
- 在游戏进行中，切回桌面再回到游戏，Esc键会无限抽风，此时剧情对话会狂跳，要随便按个英文键才能解决这问题

总的来说，作为一款科幻解谜冒险游戏，Technobabylon在游戏性及解谜上并没有太大的瑕疵，而在剧情上，我觉得还有待提高，悬念的设置不如Gemini Rue给我带来的震撼要大。
只可惜因为语言问题，可能大部分中国玩家都与[url=http://store.steampowered.com/search/?publisher=Wadjet%20Eye%20Games]Wadjet Eye Games[/url]的解谜游戏无缘。

另外这个厂的节操很硬，这游戏去年上架，但史低折扣也就五折，其他游戏入包都比较久远，不过有几个游戏上个月倒是进过豆团的慈善包。等夏促对这游戏感兴趣的可以尝试一下（有个Demo也可以试玩一下）。

其他科幻解谜游戏：
http://store.steampowered.com/app/80310/?snr=1_7_7_230_150_1
http://store.steampowered.com/app/227000/?snr=1_7_7_230_150_1

22998417.review:
Perfektní point&click adventura ze staré školy nabízející jeden z nejlepších cyberpunkových příběhů, jaké se ve hrách kdy objevily. Inspirace starou klasikou Beneath A Steel Sky je zcela očividná. Hru je pak nutné restartovat. Druhou stížnost mám na minihru Gravball. Vůbec nesedí do stylu hry a je ukrutně těžká. Při normálním průchodu jde snadno vyhrát tím, že hlavní postava bude podvádět, ale pro získání achievementu musíte minihru vyhrát fér. 22958107.review:
If you are a fan of point and click games, dystopian fiction and/or cyberpunk, then forget the rest of the review and just buy the game.  Technobabylon has the quality that is to be expected of Wadjet Eye Games and is perhaps a contender for their best game at the time of writing.  

Technobabylon takes place in a dystopian future where genetic engineering is common and many people use "Trance" instead of interacting with other people normally.  An AI named Central powers the city and the CEL police keep tabs on just about everyone and everything.  As usual with Wadjet Eye Games, the story is high quality and I do seriously hope it continues in a future sequel.

Developer Technocrat has pushed the somewhat divisive AGS engine further than I thought it could go; there are many sections involving people connecting to electronic devices and some of the best puzzles take place in this state.  Whether it is just using these devices to obtain download attachments or solving far more complex puzzles, Technobabylon stands out when compared to adventure games using simpler mechanics.  I wasn't expecting some of the puzzles and a few genuinely had me stumped for a while.  So unlike many adventure games, this isn't just a great story based experience, there's challenge here and it's more challenging than most Wadjet Eye Games.

Wadjet Eye Games enjoy giving you control over numerous characters and I found that this could lead to some confusion as how to progress.  I liked that this game rarely had any of these moments and when you were able to switch between characters, it would always be in aid of solving a puzzle together.  It's these design choices that make Technobabylon a bit easier to swallow than a game like Resonance.

There's not a lot else to say, if you are really into Wadjet Eye Games, then you will already have your eye on this.  Fans of Gemini Rue, Shardlight and Resonance will eat this up.  A polished point and click game in that old-school style and a creative science fiction story that deserves some sequels.

22868961.review:
A call-back to old school adventure games, delivering excellent writing and a well executed take on a seemingly cliched premise. The plot isn't [i]completely[/i] original - once you look at it closer, you'll notice strong inspirations from Beneath A Steel Sky and Neuromancer, including a few of the puzzles - but it holds its own without feeling derivative. 

I did have a few gripes with the game: in particular, some of the lines recorded for Max sounded very differently from the rest and the pixel-art style is less than perfect on a few occasions - seeing "half pixel" lines was kind of jarring, and there's a loose plot thread - unfortunately, one rather relevant to the plot (we never really find out why [spoiler]both clones[/spoiler] were created). The game includes an autosave on the start of each chapter, which turned out quite handy in when I ended up in what's probably the only dead-end situation in the game (no way to progress without interacting with an item you can't backtrack to [spoiler]when you climb outside the airship[/spoiler]).

The limited amount of objects you can interact with in the game's locations has both upsides and downsides - in the 90's adventure games, they often provided a lot of colorful, sometimes humorous, exposition on the game's plot and setting, but from a design perspective, less items for the player to work with means less red herrings (there are a few, such as [spoiler]the toilet cleaner[/spoiler])

In a nice touch, not all of Technobabylon's puzzles are linear: in several chapters there's more than one solution, and the game rewards you with achievements for discovering each. While they do not alter the course of the game's plot (apart from one in the final chapter), later chapters sometimes contain callbacks to the choices you made earlier.

Over all, the game is not [i]perfect[/i] but thoroughly enjoyable regardless - if you buy it, you won't regret that decision.

22855324.review:
It seems as if, nowadays, adventure games straddle one of two extremes. They are either interactive works of fiction that don’t offer much in the way of traditional challenge, or they are traditionally difficult point-and-click games with traditionally broken logic. Games that combine a rich story and world building without feeling like a DVR simulator are somewhat rare. Being one of those rare titles is what makes Technocrat Games’s Technobabylon a remarkable experience. First began life as a freeware title, Technobabylon benefits from better production values (evident in the voice acting), revamped and stylistic pixel visuals, and a well assembled adventure experience thanks to the involvement of Wadjet Eye. 

[h1] A bit of background [/h1]
Technobabylon takes place in a sci-fi setting that is not to dissimilar to what what we’ve seen in adventure video games and other forms of media and entertainment. As you sink into the premise, setting and characters of Technobabylon, its influences become apparent in its nuances. Technobabylon will remind you of classic movies Blade Runner, cult classic games like Policenauts, iconic anime/manga like Ghost in the Shell and even newer anime like Psycho Pass. 

In a city called Newton, a place where science has risen above ethics and morals, and everyone plays god with free-form genetic engineering. Advances in computing power have led to massive advancements in AI, that mostly put to use for monitoring and controlling citizens. Social media and inter-web interaction has gone up a few notches, with the virtual-reality medium called Trance giving people a platform to interact in a virtual world and not deal with the real world responsibilities. Genetic engineering has made stunning advances as well – when an organic nanomachines called "wetware" are invented for many different purposes. Such freedoms and technological progress come at a price, however, when it created a generation of addicts (known as “thralls”) who have no jobs and spend most of their time in "trance", or when a genetically engineered children with explosive bones can be made as a suicide bomber. 

[h1] The protagonists [/h1]
Meet Regis, He’s the typical “too-old-for-this" cop, and boy is he too old for this. If Regis could wear a Rage Against the Machine shirt to work, he would. Assuming people remember Rage Against the Machine in post-nuclear 2087. Surveillance cameras, computers, phones, cyborg-style implants—Regis hates the whole lot, and most of all he hates the city’s overzealous artificial intelligence, Central. 
Then there's Lao, an ordinary girl with her cheerfulness and spark keeps her partner Regis’ cynical doom-and-gloom attitude at bay for most of the game and brightens up the atmosphere considerably. In a game that has such a dark plot with so many terrible things happening, Max’s character provides the perfect balance to the mix, adding the sense of hope the story so desperately needs.
And finally Latha. She brings the game its biggest breath of fresh air, as she is able to enter the Trance. From here, she can interact with other users and even AI systems she encounters, displaying them through humanistic avatars complete with unique personalities. Here, the game flexes its creative muscles at not only providing unique gameplay, but also at delivering dialogue with wit and humor as well.

The way it shuttles you between these three viewpoints is probably one of my favorite aspect of the game. It feels like we learn a lot about the world, thanks to our split perspective. 

[h1] Puzzles n' stuff [/h1]
Speaking of puzzles, we can agree that the most important part of any puzzle-based games is the presentation of the puzzles themselves, and this is where Technobabylon really delivers. Not every puzzle has the same wealth of approaches, but in general things adhere to each character’s skills—low-fi investigation from Regis, high-tech hacking from Latha, and a bit of both from Lao. It’s a clever conceit that helps make each character feel functionally distinct even within the limited mechanics of a point-and-click adventure game. Whether its remotely piloting drones, manipulating AI personalities, or even solving how to enter through a locked doorway, Technobabylon makes figuring out how to get to the next destination an enjoyable experience. Visually, Tecnobabylon carries a style akin to the DOS adventure game classics from yesteryear, and the pixelated graphics are put to good use to create some detailed environments and character sprites. Neon colors/lighting mixes nicely with the darker contrast and undertones to create an artistically charged setting. Except for the character portraits that pop up in conversations, the game looks like an early 1990s LucasArts adventure game.

[h1] Some minor complaints [/h1]
Despite the overall positive experience, the playthrough wasn’t without its own set of problems. There are moments when I got confused about what the objects are or how they function, as it is often unclear without clicking on them to get a text description. The low fidelity visuals also contribute to the problem of not always knowing what you can grab from the environment and what you can manipulate. It is easy to miss out on a drawer or a wrench since so many useable items blend into the background. In addition to that, some of the voice acting – in particular that of Regis – was a little too monotone, which made even the more dramatic scenes a little less moving. Not to mention that Trance is somewhat underutilized too. We get glimpses of Trance’s potential, especially the part where Latha is constantly swapping between the virtual and physical worlds to solve puzzles. But in general the game doesn’t do enough with a world that has literally zero rules. 

[h1] Bottom line [/h1]
Honestly, I feel like I can write an essay or two about this game. Like drawing some comparison between Central (Newton's overzealous artificial intelligence) and The Sibyl system from Psycho Pass, whether the escapism provided by Trance a blessing in a world gone to hell, or is it merely enabling people to give up on the real world and many other topics to cover. But surely if you managed to make it this far, you want to see my thought about it. While there is no shortage of choice when it comes to adventure games — especially on Steam — Technobabylon is not just another face in the crowd. It doesn’t make you feel you are just a passenger along for the ride, nor does it make you feel like you need to be a mind reader to figure out how the developers want you to solve a puzzle. A little fix might have made game more enjoyable in a couple of ways, but the game is still a very easy one to recommend, especially since it's only 15 bucks.

22661996.review:
I am a huge fan of old school adventure games, I am also a huge fan of SCI-FI, cyberpunk in particular. Things that attract me to the genre include; neon lit futuristic worlds, crazy looking characters who often have their own street lingo, integration with technology, people having their snazzy wee devices (comm links, data pads etc), mad plots & conspiracies...The list goes on.

What Technobabylon has; A bright, neon lit futuristic city, cool devices called travellers that you can use to phone people browse the web etc, people who live in cyberspace and are very much integrated with tech and a mystery that threatens to bring the entire city to collapse.

I loved every minute I played of Technobabylon, it is a very welcome step back to the adventure games of old, in the vein of Beneath a Steel Sky or Broken Sword. The world and characters are layers deep, as mentioned above, you can browse the net in game, play games, read the news, even check your mail. The characters have multiple dimensions that give them (and by extension the player) motivation to make questionable decisions. Also something I find quite novel for a point n' click, there are often multiple ways to resolve a given situation instead of having to find the right items to be used in the right way to advance. It has a fantastic story and typical of any SCI-FI piece, throws loads of nouns at you to wrestle with bringing you deeper into it's world.

TL;DR Great game with fantastic characters & story, any SCI-FI fan particularly of things from Bladerunnrer to The Matrix should definitely check this out.

22067853.review:
[i]Technobabylon[/i] is an excellent addition to publisher Wadjet Eye's ever-growing catalog of gorgeously lo-fi adventures.  The most striking thing about the game is that it does a far better job at building a fascinating science fiction world than most AAA productions; in this aspect it more closely approaches a good novel than a game, bringing to mind great cyberpunk authors like Rudy Rucker or William Gibson, while at the same time maintaining its own creative identity.  Food, sports, cyberspace and IRL addictions, crime, criminal justice, politics -- it's all handled in an unobtrusive and intriguing way that draws the player deeply in.  The puzzles, which are all of about medium difficulty, all make sense in the context of this world and its tech, coming across more as outgrowth than obligatory tack-on.  It would be a shame for Technocrat's painstakingly crafted milieu to go to waste, and fortunately, there are indications, both in [i]Technobabylon[/i]'s narrative and in the developer commentary, that a sequel may be in the works.  
   
There are a few questions that I would like answered about the mostly *very* impressive story (especially the import of a certain apartment bombing) but these gaps don't trip up the plot for me in the least; some of these can be left for the sequel I suppose, while the remainder can be left to player interpretation without strain on narrative continuity.  The voice acting, as in all Wadjet Eye productions, varies from actor to actor.  It is never bad, but never perfectly professional; it puts me in the mind of an obviously talented community theater troupe rather than a stable of career voice actors, and actually intensifies the hip "indie" vibe of the whole production.  I did encounter one minor bug in the game -- a wrench that I could not yank out of a gear because a partition blocked its hotspot -- but it only set me back about about a minute of playtime.

(There were many awesomely odd little incidents that really helped me suspend my disbelief.  For example:  in a scummy VR-hosting dive, the player character must pry off a layer of crusted old wetware -- signal-broadcasting, nanomachine-rich goop that people smear on devices to interface their own internal wiring to those systems -- before she can apply her own and access a machine.  It's visceral details like this that make all the difference!)

21994442.review: Tremendous game; the pacing is pitch-perfect, and it strikes a great balance between dialogue and inventory puzzles, with several great mechanics to combine the two. The atmosphere is dead-on cyberpunk, and the music and voice acting is top-notch. I particularly appreciate the way it makes each scene a fairly small number of locations, and makes it clear what the overall goal is from the outset then turns you loose to achieve it in the context provided; it's a smart design to provide that sort of direction for the player. Outstanding traditional point-and-click game, which no fan of the genre should miss.

21782142.review:
After playing Gemini Rue, I knew that I would be on the lookout for any further games from Wadjet Eye Games.  Fortunately, Technobabylon doesn't disappoint.  

The game pulls you into a great story through strong and relatable characters with clear motivations that you can get behind.  It dangles the mystery like a carrot on a stick, but gives you enough payoffs to keep you going.  The real star, however, is the amazing sense of world-building and atmosphere.  Technobabylon builds an incredibly believable world that builds off of our current technological and societal trajectory and takes it in some very scary directions.  Its atmosphere and soundtrack are also wonderful, creating a completely cohesive and immersive world.

The interactions between the characters are well done, and there are some standout supporting characters that are a real hoot.  The dialogue can get VERY expositional at times, especially when the plot twists start cropping up near the end, but overall the dialogue is very snappy and well done.

The gameplay is solid, using great puzzles and exploration that make sense but are still challenging.  It doesn't fall into the normal nonsensical adventure game puzzle tropes, which I'm very thankful for.  You can usually piece together what you need to do from your surroundings and resources, but you still feel smart for figuring it out.  There are a couple of times when what you're supposed to be doing isn't made clear (as in, what your objective is or why you're somewhere in the first place), but these points were few and far between.

I picked this game up, and couldn't put it down until 9 hours later.  It is a fantastic adventure game and I give it a wholehearted recommendation to any fan of of the genre.

In summary I heartily recommend this game. I hope it gets a sequel.

21355145.review: Cool story, nice art. If you liked the Blackwell games you should try this one.

21317557.review:
TL/DR - If you like Cyberpunk, dystopian-like futures, well paced stories and character development, then you could do a lot worse than Technobabylon. (Love the reference to Big Blue Cup)

I find a lot of point and click adventures to be a little tiresome these days, some are a little too rooted in conventions set by their predecessors, while others find themselves wrapped up in overly convoluted and obtuse puzzles. Technobabylon manages to find some fresh perspective on these puzzles, keeping most of their components within reasonable grasp and still manage to deliver a fantastic plot with engaging characters at the end of it all.

Presentation is beautifully executed, as i have come to expect with Wadjet Eye games, thus enables the player give in and throw themselves into the experience completely. There were some really cool and interesting puzzles involving the "Trance", along with a lot of humour stitched effortlessly next to some gruesome and possibly even barbaric scenes. I did find that one or two puzzles that involved the dreaded pixel hunt, and one puzzle in particular involved a reflex mini-game...which i hate with a passion in these types of games.

Fantastic game and well worth the price of admission. It really shows what a quality team can do with AGS and I'm glad to see it has come so far over the years.

21279935.review:
[b] Technobabylon 4/5:[/b] Vážná kyberpunková point and click adventura klasického střihu, která dělá tolik věcí dobře, že těch pár kde jí to drhne, bije do očí o to více. Co potěší je citlivá práce s přesahovými tématy „budoucnosti nastavující zrcadlo naší současné společnosti", která nejsou lámána přes koleno a cpána za každou cenu do popředí. Co potěší ještě více jsou dospělé dialogy, u kterých nevzniká pocit, že takto se vyjadřují videoherní postavičky a ne skuteční lidé. A úplně nejvíce potěší, že v každé z deseti kapitol jde o něco jiného; jednou budete vylučovací metodou zjišťovat pachatele atentátu, jindy se snažit nepozorovaně uniknout ze zdánlivě opuštěné továrny a poté třeba ve virtuální realitě „vylidňovat server".

 Tvůrci si vystačí v průměru s třemi až čtyřmi obrazovkami na kapitolu a ani nezahltí hráče předměty či aktivními body, přesto umí vytvořit nelehké, nápadité a komplexní „mnohaúrovňové" puzzly, které ani zdaleka nejsou jen o správném používání předmětů a rozhodně vám nepomůže zběsilé zkoušení všeho na všechno; zapojení mozku se prostě nevyhnete. Hlavní puzzly ve většině kapitol mají více než jedno možné řešení; zpravidla tři v nejlepším možném odkazu žánrové klasiky [i]Indiana Jones and The Fate of Atlantis[/i].

 Tolik ke kladům. Nyní však ta ale. Předně dějové vyústění v posledních dvou kapitolách je velkým krokem zpět oproti nadějnému rozjezdu. A vyloženě naštvou občasné adventurní excesy. Je jich sice minimum, ale do takto vyspělé a vnitřní elementární logiku vyznávající hry sedí asi jako Santa Claus k tradičním českým Vánocům. Jeden příklad za všechny: místo vraždy, hledání vražedné zbraně skrze podomácku vyrobený prut, zmagnetizované ramínko a bazének s vodou zakalenou krví, grrr! Takovéto řešení by sedlo do odlehčené adventury ve stylu Monkey Islandu, nikoli do vážné a řádně temné adventury.

 Každopádně celkově sympatická, nikterak krátká a středně těžká adventura s vyspělými charaktery i tématy. Takových je pomálu a je tedy dobré si zdařilých pokusů na tomto poli náležitě vážit. Zvlášť když je taková zábava je hrát.
------------------------------------------------------------------

21123259.review:
I most definitely recommend this game to lovers of the genre.

Technobabylon is a breath of fresh air! The storyline is amazing & well executed! No annoying plotholes! Every relevant piece of information was sufficiently developed & clarified throughout the whole game.

Even though there were quite a bit of technical terms implemented in this game (which sometimes felt like I was learning a new language) I most definitely enjoyed the game! I found it very interesting & exciting!

The puzzles were of a satisfying difficulty. There was a good balance of "flow" & "resistance" in regard to game progression (for me, personally).

What I mean by this is that puzzle difficulty allowed for smoother progression at some times, and at other times I felt I was required to think a bit harder before I could proceed (without doing my head in  though).

So I was very pleasantly surprised by how the developer team pulled this off! 

I figured out most on my own, but did need to cheat about 2 times (hey!, that's not too bad!).

This game contains different fun elements:
- beautiful character design & environment + fitting music
- natural voice acting (although the way it was scripted made some reactions seem over-the-top)
- well written dialogue (made sense)
- multiple & meaningful character introductions
- intuitive & original puzzles (with some exceptions, but definitely doable)
- flashbacks
- choice & consequence
- virtual reality & AI theme
- ethnical diversity
- taboo & shocking details

There's a total of 3 main characters (which are each playable at some point, and even interchangeably so near the end, so as to have them act as a team - very fun!).

Just wished they had implemented that possibility sooner!

I pretty much loved everything about this game :). I could see myself replaying it over & over again in a couple of years from now!

This game gave me the chills (in a good way), the way Blade Runner did back in the day! It's so refreshing & different!

I'm hoping there will be a sequel to this! There has to be! The ending (as is) is acceptable, though I'd love to see more :)!

So worth the price!

20788237.review:
This is a point and click adventure game like Police Quest or Larry Laffer from the 90's.

You have to figure out what conversation or item use will advance the game.

Often these kinds of games can be frustrating as you try and guess what you have to do next.  This game takes the cake though.  I got stuck in the first room because how to advance the game is completely illogical and unguess-able.  You essentially have to try everything, and then after finding one solution, try everything again in case something changed.

About as fun as trying to brute force guess your friend's Facebook password.

20738491.review:
Technobabylon is one of those games I bought on a whim and ended up absolutely LOVING. A believable setting, very well-written characters with great dialogue, challenging puzzles that avoid being illogical/downright infuriating and a story with just the right amount of twists and turns made this one of my favorite adventure games of recent memory.

The story is masterfully balanced between serious, heavy moments and enjoyable touches of levity/humor; it avoids being a grimdark nightmare like so many cyberpunk games, yet also doesn't rely on tongue-in-cheek references to genre classics to score nostalgia points. Technobabylon is simply a fantastic cyberpunk adventure game that stands on its own with the best the genre has to offer. If cyberpunk fiction is up your alley and you enjoy classic adventure games, I can't recommend this enough.

(I'd also love to see a sequel that explores Max and Dr. Regis' origin stories!)

20716806.review:
Superbe point 'n click à thème polar cyberpunk qui va faire sentir chez eux tous les fans de Blade Runner et de Beneath a Steel Sky. Old-style dans tous les sens du terme : graphismes à gros pixels, musiques électro/ambient qui auraient pu être composées par Vangelis, pas de système d'indices ni de suggestions d'emplacement des items... manque plus que l'interface SCUMM et on se dirait dans un bon vieux jeu Lucasarts.
Le gameplay est très équilibré et varié ; on joue trois persos différents, on ne fait guère toujours la même chose, les énigmes ne sont jamais ni évidentes ni impossibles à résoudre et peuvent parfois être résolue de deux ou trois manières distinctes, et enfin les manipulations via le wetware/CI-splitter c'est tout simplement hyper fun.
Mais plus que toute autre chose, le jeu a un scénario de OUF (remarquablement cohérent au passage pour une oeuvre de SF) et des personnages extrêmement bien développés.

Je ne saurais pas assez recommander ce titre à tous les fans de point 'n click et de cyberpunk.

20521513.review:
Technobabylon ist ein Point and Click Adventure im Retrostil das mit seiner komplexen und dabei sehr konsistenten Cyberpunk Welt und der gut erzählten Geschichte überzeugt.

Pluspunkte:
+ Sehr stimmungsvolle Inszenierung sowohl was den konsequent durchgezogenen Grafikstil als auch die passende Musik betrifft.
+ Ein MUSS für jeden Fan von "Beneath A Steel Sky"!
+ Man erfährt nebenher viel über die Stadt und den Zustand der Welt sodass man sich als Spieler gut in die Charaktere hineinversetzen kann.
+ Es gibt zu vielen Rätseln mehrere gültige Lösungsansätze. Der Spieler hat somit oft das Gefühl, dass eine logische Idee auch funktioniert, statt die einzige richtige Lösung zu jagen.
+ Die Perspektivwechsel sind nicht aufgesetzt sondern kaschieren Zeitsprünge perfekt und unterstützen die Story gut.

Kritik:
- In manchen Szenen passiert es, dass Teile der Grafik viel hochauflösender sind als in den zugrundeliegenden Pixelgrafik Stil passt. Dadurch sind manche Szenen leider optisch nicht so stimmig wie sie sein könnten.
- Ein kleinerer Hänger des Spiels, konnte durch einen Neustart leicht behoben werden.

Die Minuspunkte sind geringfügig und sollten niemand vom Kauf abhalten. Jeden Cent wert!

20273589.review:
Every game associated with Wadjet Eye is worth buying IMO. This may not be the strongest thing they have produced, but it still has a number of good ideas.

There are a bunch of high level sci fi concepts put into the characters and set pieces. To mention any of them would take that discovery away from you so I won't really say too much, just suffice that it exists and it's fun to see what Technocrat came up with.

The actual writing is passable, but not super strong. The star here is really the sci fi ideas, not the characters themselves. I don't even want to criticise too much because it would require spoilers.

The actual puzzles are a mix of a bunch of different ideas too, and sometimes there are some minor UI issues as a result. Often it feels more like trying to understand how the game functions more than solving actual puzzles. But they work more often than not.

Overall a solid adventure game, even more so if you are a sci-fi nerd. It's also surprisingly long.

Enfim, talvez não seja um jogo de entrada para o genêro, mas com certeza recomendo para quem gostar!

20227881.review:
I have had my eye on this game for some time and decided to give it a try. 

It's good timing as I have been reading 1984, A Brave New World and just watched Blade Runner. I think that Technobabylon creates an excellent futuristic dystopian world. If that is something of interest to you I would highly recommend this game. There are some really good concepts which are unlike anything I have really seen before. I especially like the "Trance" which is a form of internet which adds an extra element to problem solving.  

From my progression so far, 3.2 hrs in, does a really good job of drawing you into the characters and building a genuine reason to progress them through the story. Not only are they likeable but the background which is organically brought up gives them depth. The little splatters of dark humor is a really nice touch.

The gameplay is similar to a solid classic point and click adventure. Personally I think the graphics are perfect for the style and I found myself enjoying the slightly pixilated images and animation overalyed with the detailed facial expressions for dialogue that work so well to bring the world to life.

Overall, I think this game has a compelling story and ultimately is really fun to play, as a game should be. Definitely worth a my hard earned cash.

Technobabylon is an absolutely fantastic Point'n'Click Adventure with retro-style pixel graphics.
It takes place in a mega city in a somewhat dystopian future, which felt like from Bladerunner at times. That setting bears many details which you can find out about in dialogues or news feeds and so makes for a complete world.

18825949.review:
In order to keep me going until the very end, an adventure game needs to do two things right:
The first are puzzles that are not too hard and not too easy so that solving them feels rewarding and doesn't get too frustrating.
The second is a story that is interesting enough to make me want to keep trying until solve them.

Technobabylon excels in both fields like few games I have ever played.
The setting is unique and unbelievably rich for a game of this nature, the dialog really bringing the city to life.
The characters are interesting, complex, unconventional - the kinds of protagonists that feel like old friends by the end of it all.
Dialog and story are superbly written. If there is ever a sequel, I'll be first in line.

Even if you have only a passing interest in point-and-click adventures, this one is worth your time for the story alone.
